reviewText:
Rating: 70/100


I think you could describe this WW2 shooter as a 'Medal of Honor' type of game (without the cutscenes), but then with sniping as the main gameplay feature. I personally expected this game to be a bit more realistic when I bought it... reading about 'bullet drop' and 'bullet travel time'. However, the game is very arcade like (like MoH).

Overall this is a (fairly) solid game that offers fun (casual) gameplay with decent enough graphics, controls and UI. There are however a lot of small (and some obvious) things that are lacking (or plain dumb) in the game and a large part of that is due to the AI and general game design.



The bad:
One game mechanic in the game is that you have to 'reposition' every time you fire your sniper rifle and the AI have heard your shot. The game always tells you to move 30 meters way from your previous location. 90% of the time it is totally not needed to reposition as the AI does nothing then go into a crouch position at the same spot they already were (you at your current position is not in danger).

There is a tagging feature that you can use with your binocular. In itslef it is a nice feature, but it takes away any possible challenge or surprise out of the game as you can even watch the enemies behind rocks and walls (it belongs in Deus Ex, not in a WW2 sniper game). Even if you do not use that feature the AI will still get a tag above their heads when they are alerted (at least in normal difficulty).

There is clipping with some objects. Stairs railings have no collision and I had some logs/covers and rocks that I could walk through.

AI is pretty much blind. You can stand 30 meters away on a road in front of a heavy machinegunner and he is totally oblivious to your pressence, making thus the stealth aspect pretty minimal. Lots of places where you can just run or even sprint without alerting enemies. I even sprinted into enemies that I overlooked and still could do close quarter melee kills without alerting surrounding AI.  There is also sometimes an issue with multiple AI standing at the same place where it looks like just one AI standing there, but there are several of them inside each other.

The environment sounds are lacking, it's Afrika, but I don't hear any nature at all (not even crickets) while walking through the environment. [EDIT] the later levels (airport) do have decent environment sounds, I wonder why they left it so empty in the early levels.[]



The neutral:
Graphics. With maxed out settings it looks good thanks to the AA and stuff, but the 3D modeling of the environment is not much better then a 'Far Cry 2' from 5+ years ago, though the texturing is nice and of decent quality.

The game is advertized as having 'huge' levels/maps, but it's nothing like that. The maps are for a large part corridor roads with overwatch positions and some open squares with houses/ruins. Don't expect an open world like environment it is still basically 'on rails' and linear, but with areas that allows different approaches.

[edit] Playing through the game a second time now and noticed that there quite some objects and rocks that have to big hitboxes. Meaning that you can freely look at a target in your crosshair, but when you shoot the bullet gets stopped by an invisible box around the object/rock.[]



The good:
Even with all the bad and cheesy aspects the overall gameplay is an enjoyable experience. The maps still give you enough freedom to do different aproaches and different tactics and playstyles and the game feels immersive enough to keep you interested.

The bullet camera is not a new feature of the game, but it is still nice to watch how your preciely aimed shot landed right in between the eyes of the enemy AI dude.

I recommend to play it on the setting 'sniper elite', because lower difficulty ruins the potential fun this game has to offer. Even the 2nd harderst difficulty is a walk in the park, but the AI seems to behave a bit better on harder difficulty specially after they are allerted.

reviewText:
Sniper Elite 3 - Simple Review
Great game, graphics are awesome and game-play is fun yet challenging. AI is great. Level design is very good. There are many different ways to play each mission which gives hours of replay ability. However, game-play is a hell of a lot more fun in the Co-op mode. Yet to try the 'Multiplayer' section of the game. Quite a lot of weapon DLC but this doesn't bother me as it's pretty standard for games of the current generation, and I'm happy to help support a decent game.

Buy if you're a fan of 3rd person shooters with elements of stealth, and give the co-op campaign a go with a friend for maximum enjoyment!

reviewText:
Sniper Elite 3 is a good but repetitive sequal to sniper elite v2.
there are a couple of new things maps are a lot more open then the second one and vehicle take downs add a new way to take out your enemy and also makes tanks a harder opponent then the second one.

The Ai can be easy or hard, when they are alert they are good flanking you and forceing you out of cover with grenades but when they are not they are fairly stupid with narrow cones of vision. the relocation machanic is nice helping you try to make the first shot count so that the enemy dont find you before you can relocate.

this is offset by most snipeing spots that i have seen having some sort of noise generation nearby meaning that all you need is some patiance and you can snipe from one spot untill you need to move on to the next objectitive.

all in all if you liked the second one then you should enjoy this as it is more of the same but improved. the reason i am not recomending this game is the price to content value. now if you are into the multiplayer this part of the review may not apply for those that prefer the single player you should know that there seems to be eight missions according to the achivements list not counting the target hitler DLC.

Now while the missions do have secondary objectitves that you can complete that would padd out the game time i am on mission 6 after 4 hours of play according to steam. For 40 pounds i do not think that is good value to be honest and therefore am not recomending the game at full price. wait for a deep discount i belive that 20 would be a good price to start considering it but had i known what i know now i would have waited for it go for 10 or under not becuase its a bad game but becuase for me there is not a good ammount of content value here and it is very similar to the second.
i should also note that the xray cam on normal happens on 99% of all sniper shots so you may want to turn it down a little but maybe my aim is better than i think it is.

reviewText:
I'm going to keep it short, this exactly what you've come to expect from the series. It plays great and feels great, but I also believe it's a little less demanding than the previous instalment...even though it looks better.

It's nothing ground breaking, the gun sounds and headshots definitely feel powerful and intense, but the game is easier to play. Even playing on second hardest difficulty when you go into slow motion shot it actually high lights where your bullet will go so you can take a perfect shot. This is perfect for gamers like me that don't have time to master the game, but a little less perfect for those that would like a real challenge.

That being said I haven't tried the hardest difficulty because you can't save and frankly I just don't have the time for that.

So a quick summary in + and -s :

+ Great graphics
+ Rewarding gameplay and kill shots (enhanced kill cam)
+ Easy controls (but quickly seen to be catered to console players with the weapon wheel)
+ Satisfying X-ray kills
+ Story Coop
+ A little free roam" to it

reviewText:
Sniper Elite 3 Review
----------------------------

Sniper Elite 3 has great graphics and mechanics.
It has great features as the slow motion + X-ray when killing a enemy with a sniper, these features makes the game addicting and make you want to kill more enemies.
The story is great and the missions takes alot of time to finish, and every missions map is huge.
In Sniper Elite 3 you can choose the way you want to complete every mission so you can your own plans in the game, and in co-op you can plan ambushes and stuff like that.
I don't like the multiplayer deathmatch but it doesn't bothers me.
RATING: 9/10.
I took one point off because of the price, but if you are a Sniper Elite fans / get it free with AMD graphics cards you should take it.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Better looking than SE 2
- Great new enemy alertness / relocation system
- Blow up more types of vehicles / armor piercing rounds
- Loadout is far better looking / understandable and a bit more diverse.

Cons:

Overall I find the experience considerably better than SE 2 (which I also enjoyed)  so I would give it an 8 / 10.

reviewText:
Don't buy it now.  It is not worth the current asking price.  Wait for it to go on sale.  I agree with all of the other negative reviews given here.  All of their complaints are valid.  I saw the same things and feel the same way, cheated.  I will skip over complaining about the same things others have documented here and add even more.

I honestly don't see much difference between V3 and V2.  The small amount of content and lack of real enhancements to the environment don't merit the cost.  If it was $19.99 it would be worth it.  In fact, even if it included all the currently available DLC it wouldn't be worth $49.99.

Don't let the words  ...huge
date: open levels and the exotic terrain... " fool you.  They are larger maps but you can't go wherever you want like you can in say BF4 or Borderlands 2.  You can not jump.  You can only climb where and when they allow you to.  So you really are restricted in where you can go.  The X-ray vision of shooting people and vehicles only goes so far and becomes meh after the 10th or 15th time of seeing it.  The AI quite often will see you and shoot you through walls and other obsticles.  In game the voice over recommends you move dead bodies to avoid suspicion
recommended: but as soon as you pickup the dead body the enemy sees you and comes running.  Even if they don't have line of sight
hoursPlayed: if they are within a certain range they will come running.  After about the 10th time of trying to hide bodies I gave up.  I could be inside a building picking up a body and AI outside would come running in to catch me carrying the body.  I guess they heard me grunting and groaning while picking up the dead weight?  The bullet drop-off due to gravity is not consistent and the reticles on the scopes do not appear to be calibrated at all.  So you are almost always guessing when it comes to aiming.  The windage meter does not seem to be coordinated with the reticle either.  When it shows a 2 tick wind left to right and you adjust your aim with the reticle by 2 ticks you are completely off.  Sometimes that two ticks is only a-half on the reticle other times it 1 or 1.5 but it is never the same.  Guess work again.  All of the zoom levels of all the rifles
voteText: and all the scopes appear to be exactly the same despite the in game GUI telling you there are differences.  For example: according to the comparison feature of the GUI the Gewehr zoom level should be at least twice that of the Garand but it appears to be exactly the same when you are using it.  As a result of the lack of zoom

I got points for the the shot (they are detailed with each kill) but didn't get credit for completing a long shot at the end of the map. Several other stats are not accurately kept and credit for goals reached is not given at the end of the map.\n\nI can not help but feel the game was rushed to market.  It can not possibly be complete.  Like I said

reviewText:
It's a fairly good game, the graphics are rather nice, the levels are fairly well designed, there are some good sniping features; like being able to cover your shot sounds. The bad parts; the base part of the game is short in my opinion not worth the £40 price tag. There is a very limited range of base rifles, the new upgrades to them make an interesting feature however no modifications massively alter the rifles, one is decent enough, but there is a clear focus on making you pay for any other gear.

There are some bugs, I encountered several crashes, an issue with collectables resetting the count, skipping bullet time causing lost shots, and afair few more minor bugs that were more of a nusance than majorr issue. I found myself more often than not going loud" and sniping or using my rifles in a less than elite sniper manner due to bordum or frustration.

Over all it is a good game if you could pick it up and all the DLC's for around £20 the lot.

Oh and one of my major irritations was for all the attempted realism
date: being able to wipe out half a base
recommended: have people search for you and then give up ignoring the dead bodies littered around simply to go back on sentry duty
hoursPlayed: sometimes even patroling over an area of corpses

reviewText:
One review....can change history.

Nah, just kidding. There are of course some pros and cons, and I'll start with the pros:
- Real stealth this time. Previous game had ''stealth'' but could never draw away from the enemy attention.
- Customization. Can have different loadouts (Alpha - Delta). You can also change your rifle with different scopes, stocks, actions etc. These have different advantages and disadvantages.
- Better graphics. Graphics are not really ''next-gen'', but are definitely better than the previous game.
- More open maps. More variety in maps so you can choose different approaches.
- Improved killcam. More layers when in x-ray killcam such as muscle layers etc.

Cons:
- AI. Yes, the Ai has been improved, but are still a bit stupid even when on hardest difficulty.
- Variety of weapons. MUCH less weapons than previous game.
- Ranking system. I personally think this system is a bit useless in SP, because you get xp for EVERTHING.
- Experience gain. I also think this is wrong, because you get more XP for killing with your silenced pistol than for a stealth takedown with your hands.

Despite all these things, I still think is a very good game, even for the not so Sniper Elite Vets. So, I suggest you give it a try.

reviewText:
Unfortunately the Sniper Elite series is becoming a disappointment quite fast. The new game mechanics, like forcing you to relocate, become repetitive really fast since you just have to run back 30 meters and then go back in order to the same damn place in order to keep shooting the same enemies. I get it, relocation is important as a sniper, but I can really keep shooting from the same place by doing a little field workout? That's just plain stupid.

The same goes for sound sources. It's predictable and repetitive. You can stand next to a broken generator and keep shooting enemies like clay pidgeons.  Also, the story evens, such as appearing reinforcements are sooooo predictable. Lay down a couple of mines and watch your enemies explode and the mission finish itself. I have to say, Sniper Elite 1 did WAY better in that regard.

As if that wasn't enough, you routinely encounter enemy snipers who have WAY better rifles than you, which again, doesn't make any sense, neither from a gameplay perspective, nor from a historic one.

As a summary, I get it that the developers wanted the game to be more appealing to the masses, but it's been dumbed down too far for my taste.

reviewText:
Finished the campaign in 14 hours exploring as much as i can and collecting some random ♥♥♥♥.
What i liked:
- bigger maps compared to V2 and more stealth options, more ways to approach an objective
- improved X-ray killcam (now for vehicles too), sometimes it can get buggy, sad
- weapon customisation (although every rifle has the same, wtf)
- optional objectives+more collectibles
- rank system keeps you occupied for a while

What i didn't like so much:
- as i mentioned the maps are bigger and open, but it is far from sandbox, i ran into so many invisible barriers that it's not even funny
- the AI is still stupid, only a bit more challenging on harder difficulties
- only 8 levels, can be completed in 30-60 minutes, depending on how you want to play it, how much you want to explore, collect things
- 4 snipers to begin with, this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off the most, i mean this is a sniper game (4 DLC-s already available to download though (just some random weapons), i'm sure there are plenty more to come; ty Rebellion)
- very weak story imo, and that ending is so....so typical
- only 2 maps for Survival and Owerwatch (i'm sure DLC-s will solve this problem :)
- have i mentioned the awful AI? Will do it again

Haven't tried multi yet, heard it's a campfest, no thank you.
If you can get over with it's flaws i say that Sniper Elite 3 is an improvement to V2, but not by much, those who liked V2, will like this too, i had my fun with it. Recommend it to fans only, but not with it's current price, wait for at least a half price sale.

reviewText: I just finished playing the main campaign, I dragged it out several hours mainly by my poor play,  rushing over the maps instead of being a bit more stealthy. reviewText:
My stats might say 1hour but I played offline outside Steam and the hours did not add up from my save, so yeah.

I played some decent hours in this game, online and singleplayer so lets start there.

The graphics are a little updated from Sniper Elite V2 and they look a little better, ish and I mean ish not much more.
The audio is the same with explosions in the background, talking AI etc
The controls are all the same with no real changes apart from a few new keys.

The game has some nice new features, like medikits which is nice and now you can heal yourself instead of auto healing.  I am like half way through already and never played anymore of the singleplayer.  It is not open world but the maps are big enough for you to enjoy and have a little.. little wonder around with a multiple route towards a mission which is good.

The multiplayer has some really nice parts of the game.  If you enjoyed Sniper Elite V2, then you will enjoy this too.  The maps are bigger in portion and offer some nice visuals on the side and up close with many many ways around over, through and under something.  Really good fun.

Then you notice the game itself is the same as Sniper Elite V2 and becomes very boring. Once you been there and done that you play this and you realise the game is like a big addon.  It's like what Call of Duty do with their games, they copy paste everything and just release new campaign for a £39.99 price tag, this is kinda the same but the story is a lot shorter and the graphics are improved.

The new bullet cam is improved, with added detail to when your bullet hits your mark, you get more detail ontop of crushing bone, exploding limbs etc  Really good step up but still the same game.

If you enjoy the entire franchise then you will most likely enjoy this game too, really it has some good stuff added to the game but it is more or less the same and for the £39.99 price tag, it kinda steers you away.

Personally the game is worth the time to play and enjoy.  Once you done the campaign you might get enjoyment from another repeat but I would not, luckily the game has multiplayer and you will benefit from this sniper each other and setting traps with good unlocks to help play the game.

Wait for the price to drop below £29.99 and maybe £26.99 and the game will be worth the time and money then.

Would I recommend it? Yes because it is a good game but not the price wanted.

reviewText:
Very solidly built with a fair bit of space to work with, as opposed to corridors.  There are only a few missions but they take some time to complete if you pace yourself - people who ignore bonus objectives and speed run & gun will probably find it a bit short.  If you take your time and play it like Metal Gear Solid: WWII Edition it's quite fun though.

Customisation options are a nice step, but they seem rather arbitrary and I couldn't find any clear indication on how to unlock weapon parts/sight reticles other than just randomly looting them off bodies.  In addition, there's only a handful of weapons (compared to Nazi Zombie Army 2's arsenal - still more expansive than V2 however) and you'll probably never bother with any pistol besides the Welrod simply because of the massive stealth advantage it gives you.

The ending is a little anti-climatic too, and it feels like there should have been a bit more to it, but outside of these minor nitpicks it's a fun and well done game.  Definitely recommended.

reviewText:
Sniper Elite 3 is a third person tactical shooter developed by Rebellion Developments and published by 505 Games. This game was released on PC, PS3, PS4, 360 and Xbox One in June 2014. It is a prequel to Sniper Elite V2 and the third game in the sniper series.

The gameplay in Sniper 3 is based heavily on being slow and steady with your approach to completing objectives, with an also strong focus on sniper gun play much like the previous games. What I really liked about Sniper 3 is that the stealthy approach is pretty much the only viable way to go on most missions otherwise you'll just be pinned down in a firefight and outnumbered. The stealth aspect of the game is done extremely well, you probably will be detected by the enemies whilst taking down the guards, but it is all about cleaning up after yourself by dragging bodies to the long grass, or how you escape and hide away until the enemies give up searching for you. You can use various methods to distract enemies such as throwing rocks and laying traps. Before each level you get to choose your load out, you get the choice of a sniper rifle, a secondary weapon, side arm, and various other items such as grenades, medi-packs and traps. As you level up between stages you also unlock further rewards and items.

Of course, a Sniper game wouldn't be complete without the stunning slow motion graphics of your bullet soaring through the air and them piercing through your foes scrotum, this my friends is the pinnacle of slow motion gaming. Granted after a while you'll be skipping them because they will grow tiresome as they play after every kill with your sniper, but still, this gives you a chance to get some brilliant cinematic screenshots to show off your sniping skills.

Graphically, Sniper Elite 3 is gorgeous, I wasn't able to push out full graphic settings on 4k resolution, but even on the lower resolutions (1080p), it still looks stunning. There is a wide array of setting to choose from which is always good to see. The visuals are amazing though, the night time levels really show of the games truly stunning lighting effects as well. I was a little disappointed to see the lens flare effect being used a bit too much, but everything else is truly stellar.

The game is fully voice acted, with the enemy soldiers speaking in German too, so subtitles are recommended for that. The sound effects really add an extra level of immersion to the gameplay. A nice feature which is added is that you can disguise your bullet shots underneath the sound of loud sounds in game too, which really helps you in your efforts to complete levels as stealthy as possible.

I have to admit, this game is quite difficult, even on the easiest settings; you really do need to take each level with a sense of slow and steady. There is really no point in running in all guns blazing because you will just get gunned down within seconds of being spotted. You will need to backtrack plenty of times in order to escape being detected, you'll be needing to hide in rooms, crawl under buildings, anything which you can imagine you doing in the situation you are in, you can do. The latter levels of the game also ramp up the difficulty significantly as well, as each level slowly introduces more and more enemies for you to deal with.

Each level in Sniper Elite 3 is massive. Each level will have its own main objective, but as you progress and reach new areas of the zone, you'll also unlock optional objectives, which can be things such as destroying some trucks, cutting off communication or something searching for secret plans. These optional objectives reward you with additional experience at the end of the level and also add an extra element of immersion to the game as well. The size of each level really means that you can get stuck in, and explore to your hearts content. There are countless amounts of collectable items for you to find if that is your thing too. Each of the games objectives, whether it be main or optional, will have more than one way of you being able to complete them, which will really add some replay ability to the game on your second run through.

I was a little let down by the fact that I finished the game's single player in about five hours, granted I was playing on the easiest difficulty, but for a big release like this, I was expecting something more to be honest. I can see there being an essence of replay ability due to the nature of the levels being able to be completed in more ways than one, but I would say that there is no real need for playing through the game more than twice at least. There is a multiplayer side to the game, which I tried out, but it seems to be a little on the low side of players, and struggled to actually get into any proper gameplay, because given that it is a sniper based game, most people are camping in well-hidden places just picking people off when they try and complete objectives, for me I didn't really enjoy the multiplayer.

Technically, I had a one major problem with Sniper Elite 3, and that was that the game kept crashing on launching the title, it would reach the title screen, but then just crash to desktop. This actually turned out to be an issue with Malwarebytes closing it, so it would be highly recommended that you add the Sniper Elite 3 folder into the exception settings for Malwarebytes if you run that AV. Granted that it wasn't actually Sniper Elite causing the crash, you would still expect the game to have been tested with various popular AVs like this to see if they caused any compatibility problems.

My conclusion of Sniper Elite 3 would be that I would only recommend the game as a single player title; because the multiplayer just didn't do it for me. Given that the single player side of the game can be completed in almost five hours, the full price tag of £39, 99 is absolutely absurd, and is actually fairly offensive that they can charge that amount of money for such little content. I would only say this game is worth picking up when it is below the £10 mark, yes the gameplay is top class, and the graphics are stunning, but you can pick up any of the other Sniper games for the same experience in both of those departments for cheaper. Actually saying that, it looks like all of the games in this series are expensive. Definitely wait for sale season to start before adding Sniper Elite 3 to your library.

reviewText: This game disappointed me, it has all the elements that could make a good sniper game like setting up ambushes, scoring headshots and even the cool kill-cam, but it's hampered by the other limitations this game has starting with the AI. The AI goes beyond the typical moronic stealth soldiers if that were even possible. A common tactic you would employ is to kill an entire squad run away from where they last see you and they completely forget you even exist. The AI wouldn't have been a problem if they took splinter cells' alarm system.\nAs for the actual stealth it's what you would expect you sneak around and shoot people with a silenced pistol. You can also kick generators to cover up the sound of your sniper rifle, how this muffles the sound of a mosin-nagant I have no idea.\nAll in all it was a dull and boring game to play through, it did run great though I guess that's a plus.

reviewText:
Let's face it: the only good part of this game is the X-RAY bullet cams.

The enemies are incompetent and have ♥♥♥♥ AI even at the highest difficulty. Especially enemy vehicles.
Stealthing is literally pointless unless you want to crawl around the map with your welrod for the entire game. It's easier and more satisfying just to point and click with your rifle.
The story is very poor... why even bother making a story if you're going to make it that uninspired and cold?
Don't even get me started on the cliches and voice acting.

You do get a little more flexibility in regards to routes to objectives and in which order you do them, which is nice, but it's not really a massive step up from the previous game. On the graphical side of things, its nothing incredible, but it certainly isn't bad by any means.

Verdict: It's fun for a while then loses novelty. Do not pay full price for this game. Wait until it's on sale.

reviewText:
Sniper Elite 3 Review
Sniper Elite 3 is a rich, deeply entertaining third-person shooter that is sure to please even the most demanding gamers. Unlike many franchises, Sniper Elite continues to get better with each sequel while expanding on its original recipe for success. Naturally the graphics are much improved, but overall gameplay and concepts core to the game have also received major upgrades.

The much-loved Kill Cam" is back and better than ever
date: giving gamers a rush of adrenaline and satisfaction after a successful target elimination in true sniper fashion. The stealth component of the game is also better than either of its predecessors and can play a vital role in a mission's success depending on the gamer's style of play. Replay value is extremely high for this game with the inclusion of steam achievements
recommended: co-op play and several options for multiplayer.\n\nI thoroughly enjoyed this game personally and while I do recommend this game to those who enjoy action/adventure games
hoursPlayed: I feel it is important to inform you that the game is not without its flaws and let-downs. as well. The awesome graphics come at a price. Those who are running older systems may experience lag or crashes due to the high CPU and RAM usage. I would strongly suggest passing on this game if your system does not meet the minimum system requirements listed by the publisher. Also
voteText: expect a few minor bugs
helpfulPercent: typically associated with troop ai and steam achievements. And most disappointing of all
votesHelpful: while claiming to be a "sniper" game and containing some aspects that suggest that it is
votesTotal: most often you will find yourself armed with a silenced pistol or sneaking up behind enemies for hand-to-hand kills if you choose to play missions in a stealthy manner.\n\nOverall
votesFunny: this is a very fun game and will give you many hours of enjoyment

In my opinion it is way over-priced ($49.99 USD) for a game that is over 8 months old on Steam and is also available on XBox 360

reviewText:
After really enjoying Sniper Elite V2 I was excited for this next game in the series. It seemed like more of the same, and that's certainly a good thing...right?

In this case some of the same elements were present: the bullet cam, the weapons, the physics, not to mention the awful, forgettable story. But the changes they made resulted in a much worse experience overall.

Foremost was the level design. In 2 the levels were admittedly linear, but they had long sight lines to encourage gratiutous sniping, which is the name of the game after all. And they also included a wide variety of objectives. Here in 3 every level follows the same arena-style circular motif with short lines and lots of cramped spaces - presumably to make them easier to re-use as multiplayer maps. The problem is that this pushes the player to use stealth and close range combat as the primary means to engage the enemy. In a game that's supposed to be about sniping this is incredibly annoying.

Beyond that, the flow of each level is exactly the same: infiltrate, explore, then take out the vehicles at the end. The fact that every single boss" in the game comes in the form of nearly identical armored vehicles is pretty unforgivable. It's so repetitive that I got bored less than halfway through the campaign. I knew what was coming around every corner my first time through. It reeks of laziness.

The campaign also feels more serious
date: which is not the direction the writers should have gone with this series. And while I appreciate the change of setting to Africa
recommended: that combined with the story make the stakes feel like they're not high at all
hoursPlayed:
lacking comic relief to boot. The new setting also forces set pieces that could exist in any time period - there's almost nothing tying the environments to World War II.

The one area where the game actually did better was the add-ons. The bonus missions feel much closer to what I want from a Sniper Elite game. And the multiplayer is surprisingly fun and balanced once you get over the learning curve.

When the mechanics are identical and the story doesn't matter then the level design becomes paramount
voteText: and that's the biggest area they failed in the campaign. Sniper Elite 3 kept enough of the parts from the previous games to feel familiar
helpfulPercent: but not enough to feel fun."

reviewText:
There are just things that you'll love and hate about Sniper Elite 3

The Love: The game itself
You gotta give it to Rebellion, for reinvigorating Sniper Elite series and giving it a fresh look on SE3.
The Graphic, notch it up to the highest setting your GPU can handle, and you'll see how well Rebellion texturize, placing the obscurence field for the far-distance draw and giving it the 'Dx11 feel' (aka Tesselation). Aside a few graphical bug and glitches I found, the graphic for this game is superb.
The Sound/Music/Ambience, the music on this game also act as a cue whether you're being seen, found out, and engaged in a combat. Any sound generated from any object in the game are well made. And the ambience on every level, like when in night mission, you can hear the cricket and the dullness of night, is just adding more to how immersive the game is offering.
The Gameplay, 3 major things on this one. The Relocate strategy, The Map, and The AI. The Relocate strategy works to make the sniper-play work more believable (like, when you do something that gives yourself out, you must leave the location a few distance, cause enemy will come to investigate that location), and also it works in tandem with how big the map is.
It's 3x bigger than SEV2 map, and designed also with multiple entry and approaches in mind. You can do an objective in many ways, silently taking the enemy out, or herd them to 1 place, and blow a planted explosive at their feet. The AI also is getting more smarter on this game. The AXON AI, the new AI logic on SE3, will not giving your location to the enemy when you're found out (like in SEV2), instead, when an enemy hear/see something strange on a location, they will go to that place to check it out. If things got more heated, they will also not just swarming you out from your cover. If there is a high-ranking officer in the area, he will direct the lower rank soldier and told them to move in group, stay in cover, and taking turn firing at you or stay hidden in cover until you're going into their firing range, giving yourself more hard time to deal with the now-directed enemies.
That way, every game you play could have different result based on how you want it to play out, instead with the linear map play the SEV2 offer.

Now what's the Hate? The pricing of the game
I find the price of this game is quite exaggerated, considering much of its content of the game are now in DLC.
Things like more weapon, more challenge mission, more multiplayer maps are being placed on priced DLC.
The fact that this game is priced on $50, and to get all the game's content to extend this game playtime, you must buy another DLC, is just not right with me (and maybe most gamer out there).
Maybe if this game are on the $30 range, the DLC is quite the right move for the developer (they need money, making game is awfully expensive).

That said, I say it's a good choice for getting Sniper Elite 3, it's the best semi-realistic sniper-simulation game out there (outclasssing it's own predecessor). But if you have something that made you hesitate to buy this game (like the one explained on the Hate section), wait for a discount, then grab the game and also all the DLC if you can.

reviewText:
It's safe to say that this game will be one of my top candidates for game of the year.

Let me first say that I am a fan of this series. Sniper Elite V2 despite it's flaws is one of my favorite games of the last generation". I love the idea of being a sniper and going behind enemy lines to kill Nazis. The moment Sniper Elite 3 was announced I was immediately excited and I pre-ordered it the first day it was made available on Steam.

With that caveat out of the way
date: Sniper Elite 3 is essentially a beefed up V2 in a brand new setting. Like V2
recommended: you're not playing this game because of the story. This game is all about fun
hoursPlayed: sneaking around
voteText: and killing Nazis as effortlessly as possible. What makes Sniper Elite 3 superior to its predecessor is how it takes the mechanics I was first introduced to in V2 and ramps it up and improves the gameplay in almost every respect.\n\nLet's start with the basic improvements. For me
helpfulPercent: there are two absolute standouts. The first that comes to mind is AI. While it's not perfect
votesHelpful: it's much more fine tuned. It's now possible to kill in a variety of ways
votesTotal: from up close an personal melee kills
votesFunny: sneaking around with a silenced pistol
commentsCount: and of course the core of the game
column16: sniping. In V2
column17: once you took a shot the enemy was aware of your presence
column18: where you were
column19: and they don't let up until they're dead or you're dead. Now
column20: relocating is imperative and allow to "reset" should you be discovered to go back to playing stealthily. I do think the AI could be further improved on even more
column21: but I find that I have that gripe in a lot of games.  In SE3
column22: it's now possible to use sound to your advantage which presents itself in a variety of ways including a howitzer being fired
column23: a faulty generator
column24: and even the weather + there are others. A prompt at the top of the screen comes up when the sound is masking your shot. This allows the player to stealth large portions of
column25: if not the entire level. The second massive improvement comes with the way you approach each mission. One of the biggest knocks on V2 is that it was very linear
column26: and you were forced to play a certain way. Not anymore. The maps in SE3 are humongous and allow the player to approach a mission anyway they choose. Earlier today
column27: I was on the 3rd mission and by the time I completed it
column28: I realized I had spent well over 90 minutes exploring
column29:
trying to find the collectibles (still missed some) and killing Nazis on this one map alone. This improvement alone increases the re-playability of the game.

The improved and more detailed Kill Cam is also a welcome inclusion as nothing beats an enemies head exploding after a perfectly placed head shot.

Technically
column30: I think the game is very tight. The Africa setting is rendered extremely well and the graphics are very strong. I also find that the sound design is good and it's nice to hear the German army actually speak German. I've encountered very minimal bugs which undoubtedly will be patched before long.\n\nThere are a variety of different game modes right out of the box including the return of Survival (a horde mode) which can be played solo or with a friend only for now (hope they allow randoms again like in V2)
column31: and the return of co-op modes like Overwatch
column32: which allow one player to be the spotter and one player to be the sniper. There's also the addition of multiplayer modes including the requisite team deathmatch. I have yet to explore most of the other modes at the time of this review
column33: and will return once I have gotten a feel for them. I did however spend an hour trying Solo Survival
column34: and I know that will add to the replay value the further along that I go.\n\nI feel that this game is exactly what a sequel should be. Change locations
column35: improve the technical details of the game
column37: and very welcome elements that truly make it unique. I would love to see V2 patched with a lot of the SE3 additions
column38: which is obviously a pipe dream
column39:
but the changes are so well done that it would be awesome to see.

All in all this is an excellent game that I'm excited to play even more. I know that I will still be playing Sniper Elite 3 for the foreseeable future and eagerly am anticipating what else is coming down the pipe that will add to the game even further.

8/10"

reviewText:
Got this game for free with a promotion when I bought my new GPU, and I was not disappointed.

A worthy sequel of Sniper Elite V2, the game is set in the North African Campaign, from June 1940 to May 1943 between Libyan and Egyptian deserts.
Nothing to say about the bullet balistics that are, as always, perfectly made: if you want to place a long shot you'll need to take account of wind, gravity and also your own heartbeat.
The locations are really well made, with lots of tactical opportunities: need to hide that body? Try tossing it in that well.
Before every mission, you can customize your loadout with custom parts for your rifle, anti-personal and anti-tank landmines, tripmines, TNT charges, bandages, medkits, grenades and more. You can also customize your crosshairs.
The enemy is not really smart, even at maximum difficulty: if they spot a body, they'll start searching, but I think they give up the searches too easily. They also walk too often into your traps; if you want to get rid of a patrol, silent kill one of them and place a landmine/tripmine near them, lure them by tossing a stone to make noise, and bam, you're done.

The bad part? TOO. MUCH. DLCs.
Seriously.
4 rifles, 3 SMGs, 3 pistols. Want more? Buy the DLC!
Two horde maps. Want more? Buy the DLC!
Rebellion, that's not the way to do.

Vote: 8/10, since it's on sale give it a shot (no pun intended).

reviewText: Having played all the games in the series, I'd have to say the ratings are as follows: 3>1>2. 1 was incredible for the time and a unique playing experience with many huge levels to experiment in. On the highest difficulties it was a demanding experience that rewarded patience, good planning, and accuracy. 2 was a step down from 1 in the level design department,  having far too many close quarter battles in claustrophobic small levels. It's still a great 7/10 game, but it has issues. 3 is where they really hit the sweet spot, combining technical improvements over the last two games and fantastic level design. Although the amount of levels may seem sparse, each level is it's own massive sniper sandbox, allowing many numerous different approaches to each objective. The campaign took me 9 hours to beat on Sniper Elite difficulty and I only really did 50%ish of the secondary objectives, not to mention all the little collectibles scattered about each mission. In short, I highly recommend you check out Sniper Elite 3.

reviewText: A fun stealth-shooter with iconic cinematic gore-porn. Sneak up on enemy bases, study their movements and either eliminate or avoid - your call. Knife or silenced pistol for up close, a variety of scoped rifles for far away, a few other guns for everything in-between, and even some anti-tank stuff.\nIt's military-esque, but don't expect a military simulator - the 3rd person perspective should tip you off to that right away. But it's a fun shooter with lots of achievements and gameplay that you can do however you want. Not too much hand-holding, but was designed primarily for slow and sneaky.\nMaps/chapters are big, varied, and well-done, but there aren't as many as I thought there would be - in other words, the game feels a bit short and inconclusive. Expect to complete it in 8-10 hours or so. Has some replay value - owing to the huge maps and open gameplay choice. The DLC was obviously left out of the main game at launch so they could squeeze more money out of you for it. Some physics bugs (clipping, invisible walls, etc.) in spots can be annoying, but not game-breaking. Plays very well with keyboard and mouse.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sniper Elite 3 gives the player control over a military sniper situated in Africa during WWII. Its a third-person shooter with open world stages, allowing the player freedom to approach his objectives in any way he chooses how. The AI in this game can be really difficult and unforgiving. Therefore, the player must be really careful and observant to reach his objectives or eliminating his targets with careful planning and strategy. Unlike most shooter games, this isn't the kind of shooter game where you can rush through your targets and win the mission easily. The character set in this game is very vulnerable to damage and you cant really depend too much on your sidearms to overcome dangerous scenarios if you alert the enemy. The stealth maneuvers isnt as efficient as you would expect which is why being very, VERY careful is the best strategy to adapt while playing this game. Time is also another factor to be aware of for Sniper Elite 3. Even though there are only 8 missions to complete this game, the time you have to spend on each level will probably take up at least half of your afternoon (if you wish to be entirely discreet getting your tasks done) which is how the game is meant to be played. Basically, players will have to adapt the strong patience of a real sniper, adding anticipation and thrill before firing each shot to your enemies with your sniper rifle.

The graphics and visuals in Sniper Elite III is excellent and satisfying. Compared to its predecessors, the developers of this game has improved the game's 'signature' sniper killcam, abling the player to view their bullet trajectory coursing through their victim's internal body with amazing detail. It is very stunning!

Apart from the best elements Sniper Elite III has to offer, there are a few things that hinder this game from perfection. Firstly, the AI behaviour isnt very dynamic as expected like in most games in today's generation of video games. There are often times when hiding the bodies doesnt have to be a necessity and even if the player alerted the area, the AI can be very static and predictable. Give it another minute and they will pretend nothing happened and return to their patrol routes. Second, the lacking of stealth maneuvers/tactics can make this game's experience unreasonably frustrating and annoying but maybe thats just my own personal opinion since I've been exposed to many stealth assassination games before this. Basically, stick to the old-school stealth mechanics when you play this game. I wouldnt want to consider mentioning the lack of story and background for this game because it doesnt really matter at all since the Sniper Elite franchise is meant to be a WWII sniper-simulator so lets just throw that out the window.

As much realism Sniper Elite III has to offer, these issues above unfortunately pushes this game back a few steps but that doesnt mean its entirely bad! This game will keep the players hot in their seat. It is a very fun game to play with and the visual effects will never bore you. In conclusion...

*** 7.5/10 ***

reviewText:
Stealth, long range precision distance kills and deadly melee takedowns. A major improvement from the 1st and 2nd iterations of the series. This truly defines what a stealth sniping game is all about.

Graphics: 10/10
Outstanding by any means. The level of detail is something to behold, I have not seen this much level in detail in a game for so long. This one looks absolutely gorgeous even at low-medium settings. There are also a lot of graphics options to choose from to suit your needs and to maximise your experience.

Storyline: 7/10
You have to stop Germany from building a Super Tank that could potentially be used to change the tide of war. Other than that, that is the only ‘story’ you will get from this game as it isn’t really a story heavy game and it wasn’t made to be one. You’re buying this for the sniping experience, not much for the story.

Sound: 9/10
They nailed it. The sound of the rifle, the enemies around you and even your own footsteps can be heard in great detail. Nothing more can be said of how this game sounds. You hear what you’re supposed to hear, nothing else.

Gameplay: 9/10
This goes without saying but, you can snipe your enemies with skill and precision from a distance or get up close and personal and perform melee takedowns. Setting up traps and distractions can also be very fun if carefully planned and laid out. Oh, and I almost forgot...there are “sounds” in the game which can mask rifle shots which makes for quiet long distance shots; pretty impressive if you ask me. The overall game performed nice and smooth with no significant frame drops to report.

Price: 5/10
Priced at £39.99 for the base game, it is a little too much for the amount of gameplay hours you’re probably going to have. So, I suggest waiting until it goes on sale to pick it up.

reviewText: How do I even review this masterpiece!? Best sniper game on the market for sure and the Kill Hitler DLC is simply...The best...DLC...EVER! Kill Hitler, change history, if only this guy was real. Ha. Well let's get on shall we? I had really high expectations regarding this game and they broke every single one of them, whatever went wrong in Sniper Elite v2 like the AI for example has been fixed in SE3. I also like how Stealth is even more important here as it was on SEV2, if you decided to go Rambo, don't. Seriously, don't. You're gonna get ganked and if you're not fast enough, you're dead. I like the Close Quarters takedowns you can pull off and the revamped kill cam is just hilarious to see sometimes, I did notice some bugs where for example the bullet came out of my barrel in reverse, directed at me, but ended up showing where I hit my target, doesn't happen too often but I think this is something Rebellion should look into. The best thing about this game are the realistic mechanics a real life sniper would come in contact with, you can't just point your crosshair at someone's head and expect a instant headshot on him, you really have to take the distance of the shot and the wind in consideration and adjust your aim accordingly. Great game, if you're into sniping, buy this..Immidiately. For me personally, it is the best game I bought this year.

reviewText:
Sniper Elite 3 realy is an improvment on V2. It had wider open levels, more variation in color and a more distinct visual style, and runs well even on my modest machine.

It's also still got the very satisfying sniping mechanics from the previous game without just forcing you from setpiece to setpiece via corridors. You really can choose your postition now and try to come up with a plan on how best to deal with each area.

The weapon choice is somewhat limited but really their isn't much they can do with different sniper rifles to make them very distinct.

All together it's a very good sequel to the best facist-testicle-sniping game of 2012.

reviewText: This game is amazing. The surroundings alone sell the game. Compared to V2 it is a better game. The graphics are smoother and the gun physics seem to be more spot on. The openess of the maps make it feel less linear than V2, you have many more options when coming into a base and several ways you can go in stealth or loud. If you liked v2 I would highly recommend this 3rd installment!!

reviewText:
Edit: i have not totaly reversed my judgment of the game as it still needs bug fixes, but, I have played an awfull lot of it and still keep comming to play it.
After all sniping can be fun.
So I am recommending it , but with a few caveats.

But Still;

This game needs to be patched to fix some horrible game ruining featues /glithes /bugs.

1) Using Binoculars in this game is a horrible affair.
Textures fade in and out from low to high and vice versa.
It is the worst depth of field I have ever seen and totaly ruins the gameplay.

2) There seem to be invisible walls or something for a lot of shots.
Had a lovely shot lined up, scoped to the max, empty lung headshot, Clear view, nothing in my way.
My bullet hit ??? about 100m out and that was that. 5 shots, same thing.

3) In one level I was spotted through a wall AND Shot dead.
another level I was spotted by guys 10m bellow me in a bunker.

4) the sound masking works when it wants to work, you can hear the LOUD sound and sometimes it will display the Icon for a masked shot, other times you just have to leg it.

5) tanks and other vehicles can see you behind them, Tried sneaking up on a tank from behind. Turret was forward, so no way he can see me. Well all went great till I planted dynamite, then the turret swung around and followed me as I ran around the tank, so close that I could have keyed it. So then I was stuck, move away from the hull and get blasted.

6) the Ai is crap / brilliant / accurate and lousy all at the same time.
They give up too easily. They don't notice the guy in front just got his head blown off. They hang around in the open searching, etc.

7) there is autosave AND a load last save option as well as a Load game option. I have yet to figure out how to access the load game feature as I presumed it was for loading an earlier autosave. nope.

8) The controls are a mess, fell off a cliff trying to back my character up, he turned in a circle and fell.
you can sprint in straight lines but forget about turning as the sensitivity on the mouse drops way off.
Easiest way is sprint, stop,turn sprint.
The mouse contols vary between the in game map, the main screen and the character movement and the aiming. Some feel a bit floaty, others sharp. mouse smoothing was off and mouse acceleration was off.
The option to reduce mouse lag had no effect at all.

9) The campaign missions all follow the same patern.
Get to a location, shoot/find something, etc.. and when you think you've finished, enter the boss match, some overwhelming force you must deal with or something to protect.

10) The view distances with the scopes is nothing compared to Sniper Elite.
If you want to kill at 500m+ range, then good luck.

This game thrilled me for 1 hour then just bored / annoyed me for the rest.

If you played S.E v2 this is not much of an improvement..

If you just want to snipe, then by all means get this.

reviewText: I'd say it's worse than V2, which was free a month or so ago. The guns are stupid unrealistic, you still can't dial in distances on scopes, the wind blows your bullet a meter off target on a 100m shot (in a canyon, with a gentle breeze), way too much short range (<100m) fighting and way too little real sniping. Read the Wikipedia article, sniping is about shooting from so far away enemies can't return fire or even hear your gunshot. I have a feeling the maps are so small to accomodate consoles. The COD-esque ranks and loadouts suck as well (and Alpha Bravo Charlie Delta in WWII? Have the devs never seen a WWII movie? It should be Able Baker Charlie Dog.) The entire reason sniping games exist is difficult, satisfying kills, not mowing down hundreds of guys. There are plenty of better shooters and better stealth games out there, but no sniping games as good as this could have been.

reviewText:
Intro:
Sniper Elite game series brings the same formula as V2, But this time Sniper Elite 3 only to go all on graphics instead of story.

Graphics:
Far exceeds V2
Everywhere you go there is never a empty room/place

Gameplay:
Same as V2
Sniping is more realistic

The Bad:
Lack of detail background (sky and far sandy hills}
Lip movement is unrealistic
Not enough Stealthy missions
Story is Weak
Leveling System? {what for?}

Conclusion:
Sniper Elite 3 is one for the graphic lovers, but for the history buffs.
Still it is one of the best 3rd person sniping games to date {2014)

reviewText: Unambitious and far too safe, Sniper Elite 3 is in general a reskin of Sniper Elite V2.\nCarrying over the same mechanics and realistic ballistics that defined the previous game, Sniper Elite 3 does little to differentiate itself and keeps itself within a safe little boundary that prevents it from being a full-fledged sequel and instead feels like the developers were too frightened to tip-toe out of that proverbial boundary and kept everying generally the same.\nPrimarily the differences between the two games are as follows: A new and exotic setting in North Africa, new weapons and tools to utilize, the ability to customize enemy AI and ballistics to suit your preferred playstyle and a new story. To expand on why these features don't contribute a lot to the game and make it stand out: The setting, while personally I enjoy, is not something to base too much emphasis on, you dedicate DLCs around new locations, not a whole new game, so while the desert setting is pleasant it also fails to accomplish the ultimate goal of making Sniper Elite 3 stand out as it's own title, and it's actually the most notable difference. The new weapons and loadout options I don't care for, because almost every unlockable weapon and/or part are all underwhelming, offering a minor benefit at the cost of what I feel are major costs in damage or stability. So I generally use the same loadout in every mission since the Garand is by far the best option for the game and serves to every need I require, making the loadout customization completely untouched. Difficulty adjustment is actually the factor that has drawn me into the game despite my disappointment at the previous titles, both previous games had some of the most rudimentary and challenge-destroying AI possible and ruined a large portion of both games, I'm glad to say that the AI in Sniper Elite 3 is at least challenging and rewarding to play against. Another new factor in the AI department is a feature called Relocate" in which enemies will discern your location and begin to attack if you continue to fire from the same area
date: but Relocate gives you the option to move out of the area and begin the hunt anew. While sounding good in theory Relocate can be easily exploited wherein the player fires once or twice from one location before moving out to another

reviewText:
I keep seeing negative reviews for this game, saying that this game shouldn't be played for some reason or another. Granted, there are definitely some flaws, but there are also a lot upsides to this game.

I keep seeing negative comments about how this game only has 4 rifles. I personally don't see why this is an issue. Yes, if you want more, you need to buy DLC, but I have never felt the need to. The 4 rifles cover all your bases. A long range, slow firing rifle, a short range, faster firing rifle, a medium range rifle with a better scope and so forth. There is also a good amount of pistols, including the default silenced pistol. I have never felt that this is limiting me in anyway. Maybe if you're used to CoD, or FarCry, you might think there aren't that many guns, but for this game, mainly being a sniping based game, I feel like it works.

The other negative comment I see a lot is that there are several DLCs already out for it. I can see why that might be a little bit annoying, but I wouldn't let it turn you away from this game. As stated prior, I have never felt the need to buy any other guns, so that already opts out the gun DLCs. As far as other DLCs, I havn't played them. I have not needed to. The campaign has kept me quite sated, and the other modes, as well as competetive online, also keep you busy.

Everything in the game works well as well. I have not encountered anything game breaking or that unappealing. If the game is too easy, there is a mode that makes all bullet ballistics and physics 100% realistic, which believe me, makes the game MUCH harder. The AI wasn't anything spectacular, but nothing horrible either; it got the job done. I feel like there was a good mix of sniping and stealth, combined with going loud" action. Voice acting was a little cheesy
date: but it fits the theme and time of the game.\n\nI have had a blast playing through this campaign with friends co-op
recommended: and doing the spotter/sniper missions co-op. Decent replay value with all the modes and online
hoursPlayed: plus it's fun to try and play at higher difficulties.\n\nOverall I'd give this game a 7/10. Worth the money
voteText: and I still come back to it often enough."

reviewText:
Sniper Elite 3 is the highly anticipated entry in the Sniper Elite franchise. I am a big fan of this series, and I even enjoyed the somewhat repetitive Zombie Army titles. I was hoping for an enjoyable romp through a slightly larger world with improvements to the stealth and sniping mechanics. Rebellion certainly doesn't disappoint.
You play as Karl Fairburne, a US Sniper dropped into Africa during World War II to combat the Afrika Korps stationed there. You'll navigate through gorgeous rendered canyons, valleys and deserts to complete your objectives, and Rebellion has done an excellent job in the graphics department. I was never once disappointed by the visuals in this game, and was wowed at every opportunity.
The levels are also quite large, and there are also optional objectives to complete during a main mission. These include tasks such as assassinating a visiting colonel, sabotaging a German fuel depot and eliminating enemy tanks. While not particularly original, these objectives are fun to complete and provide a nice XP boost.
Gameplay has a number of mechanics designed to create a good sniper game. You have items such as stones and flint that you can use to distract enemy soldiers, as well as a silenced pistol to kill enemies discreetly. You can loot these corpses for items before moving their corpse to another location, which is a relatively unseen feature in modern shooters. Another stealth mechanic is the ability to create noise with other items so you can fire your rifle without being detected.
On the subject of sniper mechanics, this game excels. The gory x-ray kills are back, and you can witness your bullet shattering bones and puncturing organs in fantastic HD glory. Bullet drop and wind speeds are an added factor to sniping, which makes each kill that more satisfying.
Despite being a solid game overrall, Sniper Elite 3 has a number of flaws. Enemy AI is fairly inconsistent, and will go from spotting you easily to being blind to your movements and visible corpses. The amount of bugs in this game is quite baffling, but most have been fixed due to frequent patches. Not a game breaker, but definitely frustrating if you're not a fan of bugs and glitches.
Overall, Sniper Elite 3 is a solid entry in a solid series. It improves over its predecessor, but still has the dull story and characters retained in the series. Despite this, I'd recommend this game for the huge levels and enjoyable mechanics. 8 / 10

reviewText:
Sniper elite 3 is one of the most intricately designed games I’ve played it is just simply amazing from gameplay to graphics through and through. However I have only minor concerns here’s what I like and what I concern (keep in mind I have only played the game on sniper elite difficulty and easier difficulties tampers with AI intelligence and bullet physics also I haven’t finished the game yet I’m about maybe halfway through)
•	Realistic bullet physics very well done also all snipers are completely different in stats and it can be very fun experimenting which one suits your play style and sniping skill (sniper elite / authentic difficulties)
•	Extremely smart AI (sniper elite / authentic difficulties)
•	Huge maps exploring is a must and just feels right very fruitful as well
•	Many different ways to handle objectives (however on sniper elite difficulty  going in guns blazing partially suicidal its possible but very hard, authentic difficulty you might as well just shoot yourself)
•	wide-ranging  modifications and upgrades for each rifle
•	well-designed all maps are unique from one another and a pass or bridge could have another hidden 5 different ways to cross for either a stealthy approach or a ambush point to gain an upper hand in a firefight
•	gunplay is great if any then minor unnoticed problems
•	bullet time allows you to see were your bullet hit and the damage it is doing its gruesomely attractive and extremely satisfying to watch for example your bullet ripping through the eye and peeling off the top of the skull of a Nazi officer or castrating a Nazi, yes there are testicle shots ashamed their no achievement for getting one
Concerns
o	not many weapons only 4 snipers 4 submachine guns 3 pistols and the first pistol “welrod” is the best pistol the other 2 are trash
o	the story and some voice acting is skeletal (:my opinion: but who f*ck cares gameplay is great and it give you an excuse to shoot Nazis)
o	if you want more maps and guns you have to buy the dlc’s
Overall
9.5/10

reviewText: I liked this game a lot, like its predecessors Sniper Elite and Sniper Elite V2. The interface makes it a bit more easy - not as hard as previous versions on hardest level. Added a nice knifing stealth kill. What I really miss is the possibility to shoot grenades off the belt of German soldiers -- making them explode. Certainly I did expect more maps included; the extra DLC maps are few and relatively expensive. AND of course, as it is situated in Africa, I would have LOVED if they would have thrown in some lions, snakes, crockodiles and such attacking you unexpectedly as you were sneaking up to your enemies. Or some herds of wildebeasts to startle and stampede over your targets (or at least creating a diversion). I would like a bit better AI: when you find a dead comrade in your camp, you dont just look out for enemies for 30 secs but would comb out the area I'd think. But nice graphics and very playable interface and controls. Overall a very fun game to play if you like sniping, stealth and tactics.

reviewText:
If any developer or studio wants to see a master-class in how to make another sequel - they should contact Rebellion. Sniper Elite 3 is one of those rare games that not only improves over it predecessor visually - but adds so much more to the proven central mechanics of the previous game.

The beauty at the core of SE3 (and to a lesser extent, in SE2) - is the way the game allows players to approach the mission in the best way they see fit. In the current climate of COD and BF games - going Rambo is commonplace - and that same mentality can be applied to SE3. However, it is vastly more rewarding to use your brain first, followed by your trigger finger (button!) second.

I despise stealth games as the norm. The tip-toeing around from map to map and making sure that the first two pixels of your characters' shoe are not seen in the daylight without bringing on instant-death. But play SE3 on its default difficulty of Marksman - and the game balance appears just right. You get a challenge if you alert the guards and quickly have to scurry to a fall-back location. But you also don't suffer from one-shot kills against you. It's this semi-realistic approach that makes you push-on under tension of being spotted, but without the constant fear of being killed from an unknown sniper from several hundred metres away.

However, if this isn't hardcore enough for you - ramp up the difficulty to suicidal levels with the Custom Difficulty option - including the function that disables any saved games.

That latter part is a statement in itself. Play SE3 as its meant to be played and you can easily spend 2 to 3 hours on a single mission. The planning, the thought processes, the noise cover, the creeping forward - all mix wonderfully into an absorbing and immersive experience. Your character genuinely comes across as being all alone behind enemy lines. Forget the off-map support. Forget having a squad for backup. This is you against a yet-unknown enemy force - with a sprinkling of optional objectives thrown in. That said, the game, as per SE2, can be played in co-op mode, should you so wish.

I generally don't like reviewing games until I have completed them - but SE3 is a prominent exception. Rebellion has enhanced a winning formula even more - and this game is one to simply savour and enjoy. The fact that I'm now going to cut this review short, so that I can jump back into my saved progress of SE3 must count for something!

Rebellion - I don't know what you can pull off for SE4 - but you've set yourself a VERY high benchmark to surpass. Well done.

9.5/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pros:
+ finally a WWII game that takes place entirely in Africa!
+ even meatier Xray shots - more bones, tendons and flesh to penetrate and shatter!
+ unlike the previous installment, Sniper Elite 3 takes a better attempt at being a stealth oriented game.
+ most of the collectibles are fun to find - war diaries provide the player with the backstory, collectible cards are a nice touch and the weapon and binoculars parts make it worth your while to search every corpse.
+ Rebbelion constantly adds new stuff for free, multiplayer maps and the shooting range being among the additions.

Cons:
- virtually nonexistent plot!
- while war diaries, weapon parts and cards are great collectibles, long shots and sniper nests suck a big one - all they do is give you the same boring artwork every time (a long shot is just a German officer shot in the forehead in a riddiculusly small resolution!)
- waaaaaaay too much content has to be bought!
- while the missions are long and filled with optional objectives, I can't help but feel that there should be more - 8 story missions is pretty lame.
- [very subjective] the soundtrack is terrible.

reviewText:
Very good game. 8/10
I bought it on a weakend deal 70% off and it was totally worth it. Maybe worth full price if you really like sniper rifles and sniping in general. That does NOT include Call of Duty type sniping; that shouldn't even be called sniping.

I don't know about bullet balistics and how realistic or unrealistic they are. But what I do know is that they add to the experience I had with this game. Getting my first moving headshot without help from the magic red diamond shape indicator, that shows you where the bullet will hit, was the best thing I did in this game and I felt like a boss doing it.

Stealth has been enhanced compared to the second game (also very good) with game mechanics like relocation (if you fire two shots and if you move away from the area enemies lose sight of you) and sound masking which was a thing in the second game but it has been improved in this game (you'll find engines that you can break and they'll work badly for a while providing you sound cover for your shots). In my opinion you shouldn't consider stealth in this game, although possible. I didn't enjoy being a sniper sneaking around everywhere with the silenced pistol shooting enemies in the head and stabbing them in the back of the head with a knife.

Sniper nests are a very good addition to the game and something I always use because it makes me feel more like a real sniper. Collectibles if you like collecting them like cards and war diaries (I don't see any point in this so I only have what I've stumbled across) but I do miss the bottles from the seccond game.

So in conclution: for full price I recomend only if you like sniping a lot and can spare the money and if you have a chance to buy it on sales I deffinitelly recommend if you like 3rd person shooters (although there are no assault rifles).

And for heaven's sake play on hard or custom difficulty with realistic bullet ballistics where gravity and wind affect the bullet's trajectory and don't quickscope you noob, this isn't CoD

reviewText: An intense stealth game with a bloody lot amount of gore *wink* *wink* and it's great. There are many different ways to achieve your objective, but they usually end up in at least two gun fights and a few dozens Wehrmacht soldiers les. I started playing this shortly after Sniper elite V2 and there are surely a few improvements, x-ray kills are more gory, visuals are more chiny and you now have sniper kill distance record sized maps in which you can play around for hours.\nThe game difficulty is weirdly average. The snipers will ♥♥♥♥ your day up if they so much as see one of your eyebrow hairs floating around, but it's incredibly easy to escape and or kill any average soldier. In groups these soldier can be big trouble, but if you're able to find a roof with only one entrance, in the middle of the cluster♥♥♥♥ that is crossfire and random granades, it'll be like there's only one enemy soldier. One major issue I've encoured during the game is one of the most unhelpfull bugs you could possible get in a stealth, assasination game. During my playthrough everything I blew up before saving would explode again after reloading. And since the enemy will go in alert when something explodes and if you need to assasinate someone when something explodes and you fail if that target flees, then you've created an inescapable paradox which you can only escape by redoing the whole ************* map, but I'm sure they will fix that.\nI still recommend this game because it's the only game in which you can see someone's balls explode besides Mortal Kombat.

reviewText:
*SPOILER ALERT*
So first of all let's get this out of the way, I think it's way better than the more linear SE V2, but I think It's not as fun as the first. Let's start:

-Graphics: They are alot better than V2, textures are better and more crisp and what I like the most is that the color pallete is much richer than the grays and blacks of V2. There are yellows, blues, reds, greens and etc. To sum it up much better than V2
-Enviroment: SE3 is set in Africa, where the grass is green and the Jerries are pretty. No but seriously as I said in the graphics section, Rebellion made the game alot better looking. I really liked the fifth mission's beggining stage where you crawl through a field/oasis and then you approach a big desert town. I found that a very good contrast.
-Map design: This is where the last game flopped, V2 was very linear and only one path to go through, this game has alot more open levels with several paths to go through but the general path is the same. To sum it up better than V2 but could be more open.
-Gameplay: Preety much the same as V2 but now stealth is possible. You can go through an entire level and not alert anyone. Sniping is as great as it was in the last game, it feels superb.
-Sound: I can't comment on this because I dont pay much attention to the background sound, but the guns sound excelent.
-Campaign: A lacking plot in which you - Karl Fairburne seem to dismantle the entire Afrika Korps and the Royal Italian Army stationed in Africa in search of a Nazi prototype tank wonder-weapon called the Ratte P1000. The voice acting is honestly comedic and bad, so in summary ignore the plot. The one in V2 was better. Which brings me to the missions. They are long but there are only 8 of them. The campaign will take you about 16 hours, and also not very replayable unless you are going for the collectibles.
-Multiplayer: After the campaign you can play the much improved multiplayer. Unlike V2 where it was very campy and it was essencially a free-for-all, here spotting is more encouraged and when you are on a killstreak you are encouraged to relocate to get extra points per kill. The ranking system is cumulative through campaign and multiplayer so you can rank up faster in multiplayer after you finish the campaign. However I miss Bombing Run" :(
-Co-op: You can play through the campaign with a buddy
date: and also you can play the great Overwatch mode in which one guy is a operative on the ground and another one is the sniper. It is incredibly engrosing and extremely fun.\n\nSo that sums up Sniper Elite 3
recommended: much improved over Sniper Elite V2 but the plot could be alot better. Overall not worth 40 euros
hoursPlayed: so buy it on a sale and after that enjoy. I rate it 8.5 out of 10"

reviewText:
GET IT ON STEAM SALE IMMEDIATELY!

I am not sure if it is worthe the full price, to be honest. I haven't played much, but here are my opionions (I will update this over time).

Pros:
-Graphics are good, if a little bit fake-looking.
-Model and textures are good so far.
-Gameplay is fantastic (see caveat).
-Visuals are unmatched.
-Co-op and Multiplayer fun with friends.
-Stealth is crucial.
-AI seems intelligent so far.

Cons:
-Gameplay caveat; third person.
-Ballistics are exaggerated (bullet drop is way too much, 10 inches from point of aim at 50 yards with an M1 Garand).
-Weapon balancing is not realistic AT ALL. Caliber, barrel length, action type, and other variables have no consideration in the weapon stats of the game. This is the thing that really bugs me the most (I can forgive the other two Cons, maybe).
-Weapon sounds are horrible, but then again all games are like that.


Overall, I would not buy it for $50.00. For $15 on sale, it's a great deal.

reviewText:
I recommend this game as a fan of the series.
It has everything previous Sniper Elite games had, x-cam, challanging levels, interesting plot. And here they added some new cool mechanics (Ghost,  Relocate...)
But, i would have gladly waiting few more month of development to fix some crucial gameplay aspects:

1. Praise the holy rock - like before enemies react to rocks and are going to check out that suspisious sound - but imagine a full room of soldiers, leaving one by one for the same suspisious sound and never returning and no one is alerted.
2.I did not understand that before and i cant understand now - why hand to hand close quarters stealth kill earns less exp than a shot with a pistol?!
3. Even officers or elite enemies - once get a glimpse of you - instead of shouting for alarm or taking few guys to check it out - will check the place themselves.

There are more bugs as firing into cover etc... which  Im sure people already spoke of but the 3 above turn even hard difficulty to childs play.
(Oh another wierd thing - the rifles are customizeble but the machine guns and handguns are not... just wierd)
