reviewText:
Short and dissapointing.

That basically says it all. A 7 hour campaign. Enemy AI made in 1985, one shot and the entire map knows exactly where you are. Mandatory rpg-unlock system that is just not worth the unlocks. Only 4 rifles in-game, the rest behind a DLC pay-wall. Stealth/relocation mechanic that sucks the fun out of sniping. A story that makes Twilight look like a great love drama. Unlikable main characters. No memorable supporting cast. Anti-climactic ending if there ever was one. It is all kinds of bad rolled into one, and it takes itself way too serious. Playing co-op makes the game even worse for some reason (how is that even possible?)

I absolutely love the Zombie Army games, I really like Sniper V2, but this? Even at 70% off I feel cheated.

Maybe get it for the multiplayer if that is your cup of tea. Avoid otherwise.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: A Gorgeous game that takes place in Africa during World War II. Third person action, great stealth mechanics, even with total control over movement, and FINALLY, a game which has mastered the art of sniping. However, the story is, IN MY OPIONION (my review) average. Alot of people will argue with me, and say it is awsome, with espionage and such, but it is rather straight forward and predicatble. Still, this game is so fun that the story dosent matter much. I have not tried multiplayer, but guessing from my experience with Elite V2, (the predeccesor), I'm Guessing it requires a lot of patience, skill, and has alot of camping (duh). Overall, a large improvement in every aspect over V2, even in story, (I dont like either, but at least this one is slightly realistic. Russians stealling the plans to some rocket in V2 is just dumb.) so I give this game a 8.75/10

reviewText:
*This may seem quite negative, but playing multiplayer changed the review into a recommendation... barely.

Lets get down to it.

For the price asked, is this game worth it? Lets go back a step and ask a more important question; Is this a game?

Well, a game is something you have fun interacting with. It challenges you and provides entertainment. Sniper Elite 3 is definitely challenging and it can be fun, so lets pencil in a yes" for the question of is this a game. Now
date: is it worth the price?\n\nNo. Definitely not (Unless you want to go purely multiplayer - see below). I'll admit I have not played the previous 2 iterations of Sniper Elite
recommended: but they cannot have been worse than this. The graphics are pretty and the xray cam can be amusing and fun
hoursPlayed: but this is counteracted by the clunky mechanics
voteText: often horrible animations
helpfulPercent: weak AI and general lack of polish on the entire thing. Still
votesHelpful: the xray cam shots are amusing.\n\nLevel design feels like limited paths with varying chances of getting pounced on by several enemies and shot into paste. The AI is perculiar to say the least. Enemies finding a dead body will become "suspicious" for a short time... then forget there is a problem. The noise-masking you can do by using noisy environmental objects to hide your rifle noises is a good idea
votesTotal:
but was not executed as well as it could have been.

UPDATE:

After a bit more time with the game
votesFunny: I found that the multiplayer co-op aspect of it greatly increases the level of fun you can have with the game. Co-ordinating your shots with someone else or covering each other while sneaking around giving surprise stabs to the neck is fun and makes things worth your time. Single player might not be fantastic
commentsCount: but multiplayer makes up for it."

My tip get the game as 20-30 euro that would be a fair price and don't buy any dlc and wait for sales, maybe then its more fair. But this is certainly a game you must own at a some point.

reviewText: This game is by far the best WWII game that revolves around sniping. If you are looking for a 3rd person shooter that has stealth, huge maps, and a hell of a rewarding kill system, this game is for you. The game revolves heavily on taking down objectives in the ways you choose. The game itself try to get you to play stealth for the most part, but you can go gunsblazing in to the battlefield if you so choose. The game features the head of the games spotlight killcam, which has an x-ray slow motion killcam when you successfully kill a person with a sniper. The game does progress in difficulty and varies in the stages that you must complete. Overall, this game is a great pickup for anyone looking for a rewarding sniper experience.

Review: 4/10

Although I had some fun playing this game in campaign mode, I don't really know if I could recommend it due to one BIG concern: the game is not ready.

- Bugs here and there. Fall through walls, opponents getting stuck (either where they walk or in other opponents), strange things and actions in the game can happen when loading a savegame...
- Kind of a stupid AI. Your opponents will oftentimes behave strangely and unrealistic. For example, when someone sees a guy shot to death, he gets suspicious and looks around. Then, when he's not seeing you, he will just keep walking about thinking this is nothing to worry about. Can't say that's very realistic.
- The soundmasking of shots is not very consistent. A broken generator with its noise can act as soundmasking but other things which in real life could mask gun shots will not act as the same in the game.

reviewText:
This is the worst game I've played in a really long time.

- You'll spend most of your time not using your sniper rifle.  The game is called Sniper Elite III.  Oh the disapointing irony...
- the AI is just aweful.  The best place to shoot at the player is obviously in an open space with no cover.
- AI can see through floors?
- AI can hear you through cave walls 100m away?
- did you alert guards? don't worry just run away a little and they'll forget you.
- did this game really need to be 3rd person? No.
- Controls are clunky at best.
- YOU CAN'T TURN OFF OIL LAMPS!?
- Only 4 sniper rifles in a game called Sniper Elite 3?  Way to much DLC that should have just been in game.
- bugs, bugs, bugs...
- fall from a waist high ledge, that'll cost you 20% health...
- tiny view distance, constant pop ins

I'm thoroughly disapointed, wasted potential.

reviewText:
I had really high co-op hopes for this game. The asymmetric modes sounded fun and being able to play through the whole campaign with a buddy really sold me on it.

Unfortunately, the best feature of the game is basically not present in co-op -- the x-ray cam. I totally understand that some people would get annoyed if the game was slowing down all the time for shots. But isn't that why there's the ability to adjust the frequency in single player? Removing the option entirely from multiplayer is extremely disappointing. I want to be able to compete with my buddy to see who can make the craziest shots.

Maybe it's just my disappointment but the game feels like a pretty big letdown without this feature. I won't be purchasing any additional Sniper Elite titles if this isn't included.

reviewText: Remember there was a time that it was fun to shoot hordes of Nazis in shooter games ? reviewText:
This is a vast improvement over V2. There were a few strange missteps, but overall it is a super entertaining experience. Also, testicle shots.

Improvements:
- The stealth system is completely expanded and makes more sense. You have a stealth indicator, visibility indicator, and a minimap with nearby enemies (all of which you can turn off if you're 2 hardcore 2 furious) and the game rewards you on relocating before your enemies close in on your position. Stealth and CQC knife kills work well and look awesome.
- There are less levels than V2, but each one is massive and can be played in so many different ways. Generally, they went with quality over quantity. The levels are each small sandboxes in nature, so you can plot out different paths and approaches with your binoculars and it works great.
- In each level there are 1-3 optional objectives you can accomplish if you want, and they are usually very rewarding and can coincide with your main objectives. They can involve sabotage, assassinating officers, collecting stuff, etc.
- You now have a universal XP bar that increases whether you're in single player, co-op, challenge mode, or multiplayer. Everything you do gets you XP and all of the ways you get bonuses based on your shots make your progression feel real.
- Weapon customization, although mild, still adds to the choice in your loadouts. Which, by the way, you can make 4 unique loadouts to switch between for single and multiplayer.
- There is more variety in the collectibles, as opposed to the extremely hard-to-see gold bars and wine bottles of V2. Still, it is very difficult to find all of them.

Strange missteps:
- There is a surprisingly smaller arsenal of guns to pick from. You might feel discouraged at the start by only having 1 of each type, but you will unlock them quickly as you level up. However, despite this, unlocking all 4 (I think) of each type, there still just doesn't seem enough, but OF COURSE there's day 1 DLC of weapon packs that really should have been in the game to begin with, as all of the DLC guns were in some way featured in V2 before. Strange to charge extra for something carried over from V2...
- For whatever reason, there doesn't seem to be any way of playing co-op campaign or challenge mode with strangers via matchmaking, which you totally could do in V2. You are only able to play co-op with people on your friends list, which makes it hard to play these modes by yourself if you don't have any friends with this game.

Things that were awesome in V2 and are still awesome in 3:
- Mother♥♥♥♥ing X-RAY KILLCAMS!! They are still great no matter how many times you watch them, and include vehicle destruction now as well. Instead of just Vital Hits, Headshots, and Kills, you can get (insert organ here)shots.
- Multiplayer offers a slower-paced, patient experience, which is different from most shooters out there. The matches are all totally customizable in terms of bullet physics, available guns, whether or not teams can cross sides of the map (ensuring sniping-only matches), sprinting, and so forth.

Hope you enjoyed this over-extensive review.

reviewText: What i like about Sniper 3 is you are free to take your time and really plan taking down a large group of enemiea undetected. No time limits means you can behave like a real sniper and lie in wait for ages until the time to shoot the kill arrives for you with no constraints telling you to hurry up like a ticking clock but this is present in a very minor part of the game for specific mission(s).\n\nWhat i don't like is although they have improved the X-ray kill cams with better muscle and bone fragmentations they have taken out one or two kill hit zones that were in the previous Sniper Elite V2 game - for example in Sniper V2 if you were accurate enough you could shoot and dismember the fingers of an enemy soldier whilst he was unaware of your prescence and smoking a ciggy, yawning or drinking from something....even coughing - as long as his hands were raised to that zone pretty much there was a chance of this happening which was a very satisfying thing to achieve in my opinion.......BRING IT BACK (in an update hopefully) AND I'LL GIVE A FULL STAR RATING TO THIS GAME.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I've read the complaints about this game and many of them hold little to no merit. This is an amazingly fun game that would suit a wide variety of play styles and almost encourages multiple playthroughs. Each mission could take you 20 minutes if you rush through guns blazing, or if you play this game like a smart and calculating individual, you can make missions go on for over an hour to be a ghost sniper dug into a hide. The multiplayer is incredibly fun, and encourages teamwork. My favorite game mode, No Cross, forces you to move from location to location after each shot and carefully pick your hide and be patient. I have not tried the Co-Op so I have no experience with that. But you can play a horde mode solo or with a friend, as well as a sniper/spotter Co-Op mode. I can play this game for hours and not get bored with the variety of game modes, and the sadistic fun of watching heads, lungs, livers, kidneys and balls explode in super detailed, slow motion bullet cams. If you are a fan of the other Sniper Elite games, I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Welcome to the DLC bandwagon.


What's improved, compared to SE v2:
- better graphics
- opened environments, larger maps (in campaign and in coop/mp)
- some stealth mechanics: foliage, suppressed weaponry, sound masking, etc
- weapon & character customization (based on unlocks and finding weapon parts in campaign mode)

CONS:

reviewText:
The headshot, nutshot, lungshot and everyshot has returned to us in Sniper elite 3. Now Good things about the new game more coop gameplay with friends more heads popping and of course slowmo kill cams.

Although in this installment Bullet cams have been reduced drastically its still a fair game.


ok to be fair the good and the bad scenarios...


The good:        Still has working coop.
No connection issues.
Ran great on a average computer.
The kill cams are improved *slightly*
Fun assortment of weapons.


The bad:
Ragdolls falling into the world. *Didn't happen all very much in my playthrough but was enough to notice.*

A sad thing I missed the Killcams in slow mo on every kill. *To some it might seem monotinous but thats one of the reasons we play these sniper elite games.*

The price tag, for a 40 dollar game you would expect atleast a 6 to 10 hour campaign for what we pay.  We got pretty much 5 hours exactly out of a coop campaign with taking a few minutes to get up grab a drink use the restroom and mess around searching for some secrets and the optional missions.

All in all this review may not help alot of people but the facts are if you love the series such as myself and my coop  partner then you would enjoy this game. There is a lvl 50 cap which we only hit lvl 10 / 11 so there is replayability for sure to get those stats up and unlocks.

Final rating would be 7/10

reviewText:
Have you played and enjoyed Sniper Elite 1 and 2? Then you won't enjoy this one.

Pro:
Multiplayer Coop Missions make the game fairly fun because you can rant with a friend about the bugs and horrible logic.
Contra:
Very very basic AI logic. Like a Splinter Cell game from 2005. Also some enemy sees you behind wall bugs.
Re-location is also very basic logic. Make hell of noise, kill 17 people, then go 30m aways from that, wait 10 seconds, and enemies forget anything happened.
No multiple ways to achieve goals. Only larger corridors how to get there.
Audio design is a horribly disfigured ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ baby of good audio design. (I can hear an enemy 300m away loud and clear, so I always have to sneak because I assume he's in 20m range.
Masked shots are realistic for a 4 year old child. If a small generator makes noise in a 10m radius near me, I can kill enemies 300m away without any AI hearing the shot. Is even more noticable in MP because if other player sits amongst the enemies, the shot can be clearly heard like in real life. A sniper rifle is way louder than a generator 300m away. What the hell?
Map border killzones with no warning, just getting damage until dead. Very very poor.
I could list some more, instead I just give you the conclusion:

This game looks and feels as if it was made by an Indie developer that bought some high quality assets(models, image effects, etc.) and threw some scripts in there. The focus is on graphics.

Fun factor: 1/10, 4/10 when in multiplayer.
Replayability value: None.
Price/performance: Very very bad.
Realism: 1/10
Frustration: 9/10

reviewText: I've played a bunch of sniper games, and this is probably the first one where I've really felt like I was a sniper. If you're careful, you can sit in a nest for 10 or 20 minutes just picking guys off. Everything has been improved over the previous game. The graphics and x-rays got a boost, of course, but also the stealth system is much, much better, the maps are wide open with multiple approaches, no more magical trigger-spawned enemies, new progression system, rifle customization... the list goes on and on. Probably the only downside is the limited number of missions available, but they play so differently each time you'll want to repeat them. Definitely a must have for any fan of shooting stuff or stealth action games.

reviewText:
Aaah, Sniper Elite 3, the game I wanted since I played Sniper Elite 2 and Zombie Army. Had it on my wishlist for +/- 6 months or so, but waited and got it now in the summer sale !

GeneralI'm not even halfway the game and I like it more than Sniper Elite 2. Sniper Elite 3 is located in Afrika and it has more features; the levels are way more bigger and you really need to plan and execute it carefully. Observing, planning and executing is they key in every. single. level. These 3 things doesn't matter in which difficulty you're playing. You need these 3 things in every difficulty level. The revamped and (new) features are also great !

FeaturesThe details are absolutely stunning, and as I said the new features are also. You can customize your rifle, and choose/edit loadouts before playing a level. The returning x-ray kill camera is what I love the most; the new thing about this is the x-ray camera for vehicles - watch the bullet crashing into the engine and see how it explodes - You can also edit how you wanna use the x-ray camera in the settings (or if you don't like the x-ray you even can disable it). There's also a new radial menu where you see your equipement and select it if you need it.
Furthermore, and i like this feature too, is when you get spotted you should prelocate to a new position to continue the execute part - and that's what the game says when you get spot, which is ... nice and realistic. And next to all this you can level up your rank to unlock more weapons/equipment. There are way more features, but that's up to you if you wanna see them or not ;)

The only negative note I have to add is ... If the game is located in afrika, then why are there all germans in the game. I mean it's okay but eh ?

ConclusionIf you like using a sniper, play games with a great story, apply your tactic skill or if you just wanna blow people's head off with a bullet camera then get this game.

It's simple amazing ...

I do not have any DLC and I didn't played co-op/multiplayer (yet)

reviewText: A huge improvement over 2, 3 gives you big levels to actual stealth around and snipe in. Stealth mechanics have been really improved with the relocation mechanic, which allows you to use hit and run tactics to avoid detection. It still does have its problems though, sometimes it feels like a killshot is whenever the game feels like it if you're not aiming for the head, the game doesn't autosave so you need to keep track of that, and enemies sometimes spot you when they shouldn't. It's a still fun game though and definitely worth picking it up on sale.

reviewText: Actually, Sniper Elite 3 is a very satisfying sniper game with big open levels and adequate stealth system, All sniper rifles (with DLCs there are 10 or more of them) have different characteristics to suit any type of player + they can be customized in terms of scope (including the scope pattern), grip, muzzle, etc.  There is no more stupid strawberry jam" regeneration
date:
there are medkits now. There are many optional objectives to complete (e.g. locate a visiting general and assassinate him) while completing the main misison. All of this makes the game highly replayable.


In other words
recommended: it's a big leap from the V2 in terms of gameplay and the game can boast good optimisation. I highly recommend playing it on higher difficulty levels (Sniper Elite and higher) with most of the HUD turned off to have your skills challenged.\n\nThe only problem is that Season Pass is really required to get the biggest kick from the game. It covers all the released DLCs
hoursPlayed: though - 4 mission packs (Hunt the Grey Wolf + 3 Save Churchill missions)
voteText: 5 weapon packs (tons of all kinds of weapons that make choosing your pre-mission loadout really interesting).\n\nMP is good too
helpfulPercent: but I'm more of the single-player guy
votesHelpful: so I can't adequately review it.\n\nI could have given SE 3 the score of 9/10
votesTotal: but for the greediness of devs who sold cut content
votesFunny: I can rate it only 7.5/10.\n\nIn terms of gameplay it is absolutely great
commentsCount:
so try to get the game and the season pass when there will be a good discount (e.g. Steam Summer Sale). It will be definitely worth your money.

P.S. At the moment of posting the review I've completed 3 levels in 8 hours. I really took my time and enjoyed the hell out of them. There are many more to beat and I'm going to utilize the same approach for the rest of the game.
P.P.S. African deserts are beautiful at night."

reviewText: I do enjoy the gameplay, it can be fun and somewhat of a challenge (depending on the difficulty setting).  The one big thing that turned me off, however, is the lack of content included in the vanilla game. I've never seen a shooting game with so few guns.  It turns me off, big time when I see all of this DLC for sale so shortly after release day.  The campaign is short, and only 2 horde style maps, and they both look and play the same.  There are positives, for sure: the game looks pretty good, and the x-ray cam can really give some good screen shots.\nOne other negative, that has gotten better due to a patch or two is/was the unpredictable aiming when you are close to a window or ledge.  Bullets woulld not hit the target even though the crosshair is spot on.\nOverall, I can not recommend this game at it's current price; once it drops below $20 I could honestly say that I would change my  recommendation

reviewText:
Remember all the fun time you had in Sniper Elite 2? Finding your way around ruined cities to find that sweet sniping spot?

This game is nothing like that. Most of the time you're playing some sort of stealth commando game in small maps (and they're not even cities anymore, just sand and palm trees), trying to quietly get takedown kills or just shooting everyone with silenced pistol. Graphics and mechanics are straight from Sniper Elite 2, so nothing new in that area.

This game can only provide you dissapointments, if especially if you're looking for a sniping game. I'm just glad that I got this free, bundled with my GPU.

reviewText:
If you like stealth sniper games, then ya gotta have this one. I thought it was a little expensive but after playing it I decided it was worth every penny. I own all the sniper games and like to play them all, but this one is special. The sound and graphics are very good as I would insist on at this price. The maps are huge. After playing this game more, I am  going to have to add this:
I really like the graphics and audio, but actual game play feels a little strange. I think this game was designed with the console in mind. The keyboard and mouse just don't feel right when steering this character around. You feel like an unseen entity watching your character move with your mouse and keyboard. You are 'not in the character' as in other sniper or shooter games.
It is fun, but it does feel repetitive after a while. Anyway, it is a good game but I do feel a little bit let down.

reviewText:
I thought Rebellion would make improvements to 3, based on their experiences in developing 2. This doesn't appear to be the case, as the game is really rough around the edges, and FEELS hastily thrown together. I haven't seen any bug fixes for single player missions, just multiplayer or co-op play, and that feels kind of crappy. Pretty disappointed in this title, after looking forward to it for so long.

My biggest gripes with SE3:
Bodies and weapons that float a foot or so off the ground.
Firing your rifle at a target and nothing happens. It LOOKS like the weapon fired, SOUNDS like it fired, but you've just shot a round of pixie dust, because you didn't hit anything.
Double kills don't occur, no matter HOW perfectly you line up your shot.
Long shot? How do you collect THAT?
No matter HOW deeply you're in cover, tanks know where you are IMMEDIATELY after one shot, and strafe the ♥♥♥♥ out of you.
Loading screen hints go by so quickly you can't read the damned things.
I saved a game, and the next time I opened it, my saved game wasn't there - instead, I found myself getting blown up immediately. Lost all my saved progress and had to start the level over.
Enemy AI can apparently see you around corners, and through cover, and will immediately start firing at you, even though you can't see them.

reviewText:
The thing I like most about this game is how it's improved since V2. The controls all feel very familiar,  that is to say there's nothing too different about the layout of what-does-what and it's responsive on top of it, even though I still find it a little annoying that you have to take cover behind a crotch-high wall before you can vault over it instead of.. well, -just- vaulting over it. Or perhaps I'm just doing it wrong.

You can definitely see that a lot of the effort has gone into the the gory, slow-mo shots where you can see, in close and loving detail, a bullet drill right the way through a poor sod's head, splattering brains, blood and bone everywhere. The only nit-pick I have with it though [honestly, I don't mean to sound like a grim and creepy fellow with this] is that after watching my bullet bore it's way through a man's face and exit with what appears like it should have left a wound the size of a grapefruit, there appears to be little damage to the individual. I've clearly surgically removed several unfortunate blokes' faces with a conservative amount of bullets but when I trot on over to the corpse, those eyes I've taken great care to get rid of are still there. No halves of skull missing or gaping craters where you would assume there'd be a considerable exit wound; kind of makes the gorey, attention to detail of the anatomy side of things feel a little bit half-arsed. But I'll overlook that as it probably is a rather large amount of work to do.

Despite this, the game is great fun. Skulking around in the shadows, being able to plan a method of attack from any and all directions instead of the usual, linear path a game can normally give you. Shadows even affect how concealed you are and there are even some lanterns that can be shot to cast a bit more shadow at that; a feature I though V2 desperately needed. The whole relocation mechanic is great as well; forcing you to stay on your toes and not get too comfy in one spot. It adds a bit more of a pace to the game and add a tad more realism to the experience in that a sniper can only take so many shots from the same location, even though realistically a sniper can wait in one spot for days defacating in their pants for even just one good shot.

But in all; I do have a couple of huge gripes with this game:
We'll start with the length of the game; eight levels stardard just isn't enough for a full price, hyped up title like this. If you know what you're doing you can fly through those levels in less than a day and it's never a good sign when your players get the the end and sigh saying Is that all?". Also
date: not including DLC [which I'll get to]
hoursPlayed: maching guns and pistols. Really? This game is called -Sniper Elite- and there's only four rifles? What annoys me even more is that the protagonist clearly has a Kar98 on his back in the box art and not only is it not in the game; it's not even DLC. So to even have a nice veriety of guns and even have just more than one thing to do in the survival mode and multiplayer modes you -have- to buy the DLC that came out on day one with the game [and others
voteText: now that there's another out I believe]. Why not just include it in the full game? That seems a bit money-grubby to me and like Rebellion has done the fans a bit of a disservice there just make a bit of extra pocket money.\n\nHowever despite the length of the game and the seemingly greedy intentions of having a very limited arsenal included
helpfulPercent:
it's a very solid and very fun game. Definitely worth a go. But to be fair; I wish I didn't spend as much as I did on it for the amount of game I actually got on purchase.
A 3.5/5 from me

- Matt"

reviewText:
Rebellion clearly had good intentions. Sniper Elite 3 is far more open-ended, and offers a much wider variety of playstyles than what V2 did. It’s only too bad then that the end product just doesn’t feel competent enough to satisfy its own ambition. It has all the features required to make the ultimate sniping game. But not enough time and effort was given to iron out and polish up each of these features to the levels that would make the game shine. Let’s hope Rebellion take everything they’ve learned so far, and turns the next sequel into what this game was so close to becoming, had it only been in development for a little longer; the benchmark that all future sniping games will be measured against. For its retail price, I can really only recommend it to those with a serious fetish for sniping. At a good discount or with some heavy patches ironing out all the issues, I would have less of a problem recommending it to anyone out for a good time shooting Nazis. Because although it’s not saying much, Sniper Elite 3 is currently the best game entirely devoted to sniping that we’ve gotten so far.

3.5/5

Full Review:
http://www.pixeljudge.com/en/reviews/sniper-elite-3/

reviewText:
The AI in solo mode is terrible.  The bad guys either all have ESP and can hit you from the moment they arrive, or - in lower difficulty modes - they are cardboard targets that stand there and get shot by you.

I can't stand shooter games that have lazy collision modeling.  In other words, if I'm looking down my barrel and have an unobstructed view of my target I should not be bouncing bullets off of the window or ledge I'm looking over.

Also, there is no excuse for a sandbox" environment that contains uncrossable non-obstacles.  If my guy can jump and climb up a ledge I should not be forced to walk around a 25 cm tall pile of flat steel sheets.  This is one of those games that is frustratingly almost good - but because it's so close it is inexcusable that it would have such glaring 1990's style limitations."

I found this game to be seriously underwhelming.

The maps have improved alot since V2 with most of the levels being open" and expansive but you wil still feel like you get bottlenecked into some situations where there is only one option to progress in the game.

On the lower difficulties the AI is as dumb as a bag of gravle and at most they will give you the challange of a cardboard cutout.

Vehicles and tanks have the ability to spot you immediately when you exit your hideouts and
to me it seems a tad wrong that a enclosed tincan of a tank
can spot you faster than a sentry in one of the lookout towers.

Slight spoiler ahead :
----------------
At one point in the game i have to witness a conversation between three officers to progress along in the game.
To trigger this event i had to climb a scaffold and spy on them from above
date:
First time doing this i started climing down the ladder again to get a better vantage point but that resulted in the mission failing.

I hate this kind of gamey logic where one wrong step can result in a failed state without any chance of redemtion.
----------

Personally i found the game to be way too short and it doesn't leave me with the desire to purchase DLC or even replay the game again.

Although i give this game a hard time there is some fun to be had and it is a clear upgrade comparing to V2.
If i hadn't bought this game i would wait for a sale unless you really really want to play around with thoes XRAY kill shots."

reviewText:
Singleplayer: Taking into account that this is a game about sneaking and sniping, I still find it pretty boring. It's basically a prettier Sniper Elite II, with a hint of gun customization.

Multiplayer: It is the antithesis of Call of Duty. Depending on who you ask (me), even if you dislike run-and-gun shooters on some level, this doesn't actually make this game any more appealing.

But it does have good bullet physics and killcams, and - let's face it - this is probably why you're even thinking about buying this in the first place.

6/10. Even if you're interested in it now while it's at full price, I'd advise you to wait till it's $15. Because IMHO, that's what it's worth.

reviewText: As much as I enjoyed playing Sniper Elite V2, I cannot say that I had a good time playing Sniper Elite III. It looks very unfinished and the bugs that I ran into demolished my entire gameplay experience. The game itself looks really nice graphics wise, running on a GTX 770. The maps are much larger and open than in its predecessor but you still have to struggle with the annoying spawn mechanics, whereas you can take a look at an obvious spot for an enemy sniper (like a tower) and spot nobody. And while you approach it BOOM there he is, spawned out of nowhere as you are getting closer. The shooting distances are often very short and the game feels more like a close-quarter hide-and-seek game for kids.\n\nI should have saved the 40€ I paid when it was on pre-order. A real disappointment.

reviewText: I've got my money's worth from this game. This is something I made sure of especially as I originally had purchased a copy from a vender that was not steam, and therefore was deemed stolen" by Rebellion and revoked. But I won't turn this review into a rant about that
date:
I paid my £40 and have played Sniper Elite 3 now for about 40 odd hours.

I've completed the game on Sniper Elite mode. I've completed it on Authentic mode. I've collected all the collectables. Completed all the bonus objectives. I've completed the DLC and obtained all the achievements from that.

I've got (at the time of writing) 54/61 achievements for SE3 and I'm almost at the point of a perfect game. Once there I think I won't bother with this game again.

You see
hoursPlayed:
MASSIVE sniper elite and sniper elite v2 fan. I also loved the v2 zombie nazi DLC/standalone's too (although truth be told I haven't yet finished both). I was really looking forward to SE3. I had been following its progression for a while and tried not to get too excited because I didn't want to spoil the joy of release day.

When its release day finally came around (and all the BS of getting an actual copy aside) the initial 10 minutes of the game were brilliant!

It looked great
voteText: colours were vibrant and lush. The sound was crisp and map design was classic. I went through the tutorial really enjoying what I was doing

votesFunny: AI shooting through walls at me

column16: BULLETPROOF grass and bushes
column17: AI that suddenly spawned in areas you had previously cleared

column19: falling through the map when proning near walls
column20: standard stuff that should have been found and fixed during development by Rebellions QA.\n\nThese issues continued to plague my experience throughout the game. I should have stopped then and there and got a refund due to a grossly unfinished product
column21: but I continued on because I really wanted to enjoy it being a massive fan of the franchise. I eventually committed too much time that stopping would have annoyed me just as much as all the issues and bugs I was experiencing
column22: so I just decided to grin and bear it and try to 100% the game and then "put i on the shelf" and never think about it again.\n\nI don't really know if Rebellion will ever really fix all the problems this game currently has because there are so many. reviewText: EPIC\n
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
For me, personally:
PRO:
-Good looking game. Textures are off in some places but that's not a huge deal.
-It can get very brutal in a high difficulty.
-They learned after SE:v2 and improved a lot of things.
-Weapons and how you can have a tailored to you variety. (mostly)
-I wouldn't say it's a long game, but it's not really short either. Nice middle ground.
-A lot of the time, movements are predictable - but there has been the odd time where I have been caught out and seen.
-I have came across only 1 bug - ONE - which was easily resolved by restarting the level. This can be a con, but to me it's not.
-Cinematics are short and sweet, but can be skipped anyway.

CON:
-Sound and sound masking seem to still be quite off and unrealistic.
-Night missions; enemies can see like it's day, but for someone like me that uses low contrast for ambiance can't see them.
-Although I said weapons can be tailored, it's still a choice between this, that or the other. You can't be a run and gun person effeciently.
-I feel the scope and the aim helper are off sometimes. The helper said I had a hit, I shoot, and the bullet flies above or past them. (Note: I had this very few times. This could be just a mechanic to not make it a faceroll? No idea)
-Killed a guard, someone found the body. That someone just looks around, shrugs their shoulders and carries on patrol. No alarms or searching the area or at least gave the corpse a cup of tea. Nope, like nothing happened.
-You get seen or heard from a shot and get chased to where you were last. Relocate, get an all clear and everyone just goes back to normal... again like nothing happened. This universe plays devilish tricks, I tell ye.

That's all I can think of for now. Do I think the price tag is worth the game? drop the price to £29.99 and then yes, it would be VERY worth the money I would think.

TL;DR: IMO, a very good game, but has it's offsets by AI and sound masking.

reviewText:
I thought Rebellion would make improvements to 3, based on their experiences in developing 2. This doesn't appear to be the case, as the game is really rough around the edges, and FEELS hastily thrown together. I haven't seen any bug fixes for single player missions, just multiplayer or co-op play, and that feels kind of crappy. Pretty disappointed in this title, after looking forward to it for so long.

My biggest gripes with SE3:
Bodies and weapons that float a foot or so off the ground.
Firing your rifle at a target and nothing happens. It LOOKS like the weapon fired, SOUNDS like it fired, but you've just shot a round of pixie dust, because you didn't hit anything.
Double kills don't occur, no matter HOW perfectly you line up your shot.
Long shot? How do you collect THAT?
No matter HOW deeply you're in cover, tanks know where you are IMMEDIATELY after one shot, and strafe the ♥♥♥♥ out of you.
Loading screen hints go by so quickly you can't read the damned things.
I saved a game, and the next time I opened it, my saved game wasn't there - instead, I found myself getting blown up immediately. Lost all my saved progress and had to start the level over.
Enemy AI can apparently see you around corners, and through cover, and will immediately start firing at you, even though you can't see them.

reviewText:
The AI in solo mode is terrible.  The bad guys either all have ESP and can hit you from the moment they arrive, or - in lower difficulty modes - they are cardboard targets that stand there and get shot by you.

I can't stand shooter games that have lazy collision modeling.  In other words, if I'm looking down my barrel and have an unobstructed view of my target I should not be bouncing bullets off of the window or ledge I'm looking over.

Also, there is no excuse for a sandbox" environment that contains uncrossable non-obstacles.  If my guy can jump and climb up a ledge I should not be forced to walk around a 25 cm tall pile of flat steel sheets.  This is one of those games that is frustratingly almost good - but because it's so close it is inexcusable that it would have such glaring 1990's style limitations."

reviewText:
I found this game to be seriously underwhelming.

The maps have improved alot since V2 with most of the levels being open" and expansive but you wil still feel like you get bottlenecked into some situations where there is only one option to progress in the game.

On the lower difficulties the AI is as dumb as a bag of gravle and at most they will give you the challange of a cardboard cutout.

Vehicles and tanks have the ability to spot you immediately when you exit your hideouts and
to me it seems a tad wrong that a enclosed tincan of a tank
can spot you faster than a sentry in one of the lookout towers.

Slight spoiler ahead :
----------------
At one point in the game i have to witness a conversation between three officers to progress along in the game.
To trigger this event i had to climb a scaffold and spy on them from above
date:
First time doing this i started climing down the ladder again to get a better vantage point but that resulted in the mission failing.

I hate this kind of gamey logic where one wrong step can result in a failed state without any chance of redemtion.
----------

Personally i found the game to be way too short and it doesn't leave me with the desire to purchase DLC or even replay the game again.

Although i give this game a hard time there is some fun to be had and it is a clear upgrade comparing to V2.
If i hadn't bought this game i would wait for a sale unless you really really want to play around with thoes XRAY kill shots."

reviewText:
Singleplayer: Taking into account that this is a game about sneaking and sniping, I still find it pretty boring. It's basically a prettier Sniper Elite II, with a hint of gun customization.

Multiplayer: It is the antithesis of Call of Duty. Depending on who you ask (me), even if you dislike run-and-gun shooters on some level, this doesn't actually make this game any more appealing.

But it does have good bullet physics and killcams, and - let's face it - this is probably why you're even thinking about buying this in the first place.

6/10. Even if you're interested in it now while it's at full price, I'd advise you to wait till it's $15. Because IMHO, that's what it's worth.

reviewText: As much as I enjoyed playing Sniper Elite V2, I cannot say that I had a good time playing Sniper Elite III. It looks very unfinished and the bugs that I ran into demolished my entire gameplay experience. The game itself looks really nice graphics wise, running on a GTX 770. The maps are much larger and open than in its predecessor but you still have to struggle with the annoying spawn mechanics, whereas you can take a look at an obvious spot for an enemy sniper (like a tower) and spot nobody. And while you approach it BOOM there he is, spawned out of nowhere as you are getting closer. The shooting distances are often very short and the game feels more like a close-quarter hide-and-seek game for kids.\n\nI should have saved the 40€ I paid when it was on pre-order. A real disappointment.

reviewText: I've got my money's worth from this game. This is something I made sure of especially as I originally had purchased a copy from a vender that was not steam, and therefore was deemed stolen" by Rebellion and revoked. But I won't turn this review into a rant about that
date:
I paid my £40 and have played Sniper Elite 3 now for about 40 odd hours.

I've completed the game on Sniper Elite mode. I've completed it on Authentic mode. I've collected all the collectables. Completed all the bonus objectives. I've completed the DLC and obtained all the achievements from that.

I've got (at the time of writing) 54/61 achievements for SE3 and I'm almost at the point of a perfect game. Once there I think I won't bother with this game again.

You see
hoursPlayed:
MASSIVE sniper elite and sniper elite v2 fan. I also loved the v2 zombie nazi DLC/standalone's too (although truth be told I haven't yet finished both). I was really looking forward to SE3. I had been following its progression for a while and tried not to get too excited because I didn't want to spoil the joy of release day.

When its release day finally came around (and all the BS of getting an actual copy aside) the initial 10 minutes of the game were brilliant!

It looked great
voteText: colours were vibrant and lush. The sound was crisp and map design was classic. I went through the tutorial really enjoying what I was doing

column16: BULLETPROOF grass and bushes

column20: standard stuff that should have been found and fixed during development by Rebellions QA.\n\nThese issues continued to plague my experience throughout the game. I should have stopped then and there and got a refund due to a grossly unfinished product
column21: but I continued on because I really wanted to enjoy it being a massive fan of the franchise. I eventually committed too much time that stopping would have annoyed me just as much as all the issues and bugs I was experiencing
column22: so I just decided to grin and bear it and try to 100% the game and then "put i on the shelf" and never think about it again.\n\nI don't really know if Rebellion will ever really fix all the problems this game currently has because there are so many. reviewText: I pre-purchsed Sniper Elite 3 as I had already bought Sniper Elite 2 + all the DLC's for SE2 and thoroughly enjoyed every minute of the entire package. I'd gone through the campaign several times, mostly at Marksman level (my personal favourite - I enjoy lining the diamond up for a shot), but also at Sniper Elite, mostly for the achievement. Sniper Elite 2, after hundreds of hours playing time is still a game I like to 'dip back into'; play a particular level in a different way, setting myself a particular challenge or go for an obscure achievement, or just play for the extra points and pure pleasure of the graphics and settings. This cannot be said for all campaign WWII shooters, some can get very predictable and can only be played in a certain way which you will realise after only a couple of plays through, so I'm really pleased to be in the Sniper Elite camp. Sniper Elite 3 proved to be even more superior in all aspects than SE2. Once again, hundreds of hours into the game and I am still looking forward to playing each mission over and over again. Still finding areas of the maps I havent explored, and after maybe 5 times through I can honestly say each time has been a completely different experience. The only thing that will hold you back as you sneak through the North African settings will be your own imaginative methods and skills. The cam-kills never get dull for me, and being able to retain stealth while I systematically silence and destroy airfields/factory's/gun emplacements etc is truly satisfying. One (constructive) criticism is the subdued enemy response to my attacks. While it really is real fun to creep through missions sniping with sound cover or silently downing enemies as I tag and find them, sometimes it seems the realism is lost as after a short period of 'alertness', comrades of the dead just seem to resign themselves to the fact that the garrison (or whatever it is) they are stationed at is slowly but surely being annihilated. There is no heightened sense of alarm. It is possible to hide bodies, which is an amazing feature, but what with the enemy not seeming to care too much, after a minute or so, that another of their comrades has been found dead, there wasn't a great deal of incentive to use it for me. I won't comment on the MP as I haven't played it enough to appreciate it, but definitely from what I have played its all thumbs up from me. Atmospheric, tense and immersive, and definitely a game you will go back to over and over again. More Sniper Elite (4?) please : -)

reviewText:
This game was good, but not worth the price, it would be better suited at 20 or so dollars instead.

The game has great missions, and a large amount of flexibility with your approach, but I had some technical problems.

The game would crash everytime I died, and sometimes just randomly, and whenever I walked near a small prop like a crate my camera angle would shift into the air and start spinning until I had moved away.

Story 9/10
Graphics 10/10
Price 4/10
Gameplay 8/10
Controls 7/10 (Not as fluid as I would have liked I.E. too many buttons to press, but managleable)
Extras (collectables, side missions, ect.) 9/10
OVERALL 7.5/10 (would be 8/10 but price set it down)

reviewText: A unique gamming experience for the WW2 buffs among us.  Sniper Elite 3 has improved upon the previous games in terms of visuals and gameplay.  The ability to shoot without sound cover and rellocate has fundamentally enhanced the game.  At times the visuals can be very cinematic.  As with every game, this one is not without its faults.  Gameplay can become alittle mechanical in feel (shoot, relocate, shoot, relocate) as well as the repetitive kill cam which is intriquing  at first but became overplayed.  If I could change one thing about this game it would be the addition of more story. Missions are not very plot driven.  It feels less like a WW2 sniper adventure and more like being dropped into a map with a checklist.  All defaults aside this is still a great game worthy of a playthrough.  The Afrika Korp backdrop is well executed.  I feel that Sniper Elite 3 is a fair improvement from its predecessors and a great foundation to continue to expand the genre.

reviewText:
I bought this as i love playing the role of the lone sniper, something i did successfully with Wolfenstein.
What this game offers is a dedicated role as a sniper with varying degrees of realism with fantastic levels interesting missions and a good storyline
If you are into games where you have to think and setup your attacks and want an immersive and very challenging experience then i would recommend SE3
The game play is very rewarding and it has to be said downright frustrating at times depending on the level of realism you have selected the loadout (weapon selection & customisation) takes some setting up but once you have sorted that you can settle down and enjoy ! the setting up of a shot is very rewarding indeed waiting for the target then achieving the mission is all the stuff of latent schoolboy fantasies i thouroughly enjoyed this game im now gonna do SE V2 as i just love the whole silent killer very rewarding (years of playing Thief haha) . . . for a greater challenge there is the multiplayer which is again equal in its rewards and frustrations !!

reviewText:
This review is ENTIRELY based on CO-op play only!

The game is Good
- You cannot play it like an action game, take it slow and easy
- The game is edged towards sniper shooting therefore, only the sniper gets all the love for customizations
- Don't look for realism, it's not meant to be so
- Only 8 Missions = Almost 3 hrs or so per mission, DLC's add more
- Play co-op, a lot more fun.

What's not to like:-
- The game is not really well designed for Co-op, if one player dies, the game will start from Last check point, there is no drop in and drop off in the game, also if by chance anyone disconnects, you cannot save the game, but WILL have to play ALL the way from the START. This SUX when you've finished everything but the last objective after a 3 hr mission level.
- It is not Assassin's creed, it is not a close quarters stealth game BUT appears to be. The game actually deviates from previous Sniper Elite games in this regard as more often than not, you'll actually be taking enemies down with your silenced pistol close up.
- Close quarters is clunky, use silenced pistol instead as NOT ALL situations lend to taking silent take-downs, this is by design and incredibly silly as it's not intuitive.
- One shot from the sniper gun and the ENTIRE base is almost on you.
- Far too much emphasis on Sniper gun only, everything and the kitchen sink is thrown into it, other guns' accuracy and damage is purposely kept lower.
- Far too much emphasis on Headshots to take down, seriously! Come on. Give extra XP for it, Don't make a player shoot twice just cause he hit at the torso.
- Every mission becomes tediously long of about 3 hrs if you play it slow and hidden in the game.

reviewText:
Another entry in the Sniper Elite franchise. And boy, it's a great one.

Story: The story might not feel very deep, but it works.

Graphics: The graphics are absolutely fantastic. Look at the beautiful enviroments of North Africa. Definatively Scenery Porn (look it up on Tv tropes). The character models also look very good. Even on low settings it's impressive.

Gameplay: The gameplay is in my opinion, improved a bit from V2. While regenerating health still exists, now it will only fill up to a certain point of your lifebar, anymore injuries than that will require bandages or medpacks to heal. The shooting still works very nice. One flaw though is that they removed the cover system from V2 (press Q), but so far it hasn't been affecting me that much. The A.I shows some improvement from V2, they will now react more to suspicious stuff, like gunfire and dead bodies. If you kill a soldier, they will start searching for you, and will find you eventually unless you relocate. You can also occasionally find weapon parts or upgrades for your weapons which can be used to modify your weapons.

Music: The music is, like V2, epic and well made. You can even occasionally hear songs from V2 on the radios in some missions.

Overall, Sniper Elite 3 is worth the money. If you liked V2, you will enjoy 3 as well.

Also for the last, it has trading cards, and the X-Ray killcams are just absolutely AWESOME (shooting an enemy in some parts of the head will even DESTROY parts of the cranium).

9/10.

reviewText:
Sniper Elite 3 is a fun casual sniper game.  I'm giving it a thumbs up because by itself its an alright game.  However that said, I'd like to point out that in my opinion this game is a step back from Sniper Elite v2.  Here's how the two compare in my opinion:

Improvements:

- less linear maps
- improved graphics
- more customizable weapons

Cons:

- Empty lung ability now shows where to aim to adjust for gravity and wind (even on the hardest difficulty).  Sniper Elite v2 is incredibly fun when you get dialed in to a rifle and pull of numerous long range consecutive headshots.  You'll do that in SE3 as well, but it'll be so easy you won't even notice.
- The new detection mechanics are broken. While SEv2's were admittedly pretty simple SE3's is just to wonky to ignore.  Get caught in your sniping nest?  No worries, walk 50 meters away, then walk back and the Nazis will forget all about where you've been picking them off from for the past 10 minutes.
- Poor clipping on cover.  It's always annoying when you shoot the barrier in front of you when your scope shows a clear shot, but this is especially bad in SE3 where the detection mechanism penalizes you for every shot.
- Poor checkpoint system.  Sometimes it saves after objectives, sometimes it saves when you're sitting in a bush, and sometimes it doesn't save at all.

reviewText:
Heyyo,

So I just beat the campaign to Sniper Elite 3 (played on Sniper Elite difficulty) and it was pretty good! The sniper gameplay is much like Sniper Elite V2 with a fresh coat of paint... and wow is it a lovely coat of paint. The graphics are phenomenal and the game runs so damn good too! They really brought the Afrika Korps to life in this game. You'll see beautifully rendered Panzer III and IV tanks, including the British Matilda... there's also the Tiger I Tank that looks badass.

The sound effects are the next improvement... wow I love the sounds of the guns in this game. The MP 40 especially. The way it sounds when it fires or reloads is fantastic! I also love that creepy sound the game makes when enemy snipers are trying to get a bead on you or when enemies go into combat mode... kinda reminds me of 70's horror movie sound effects when the killer is sneaking up on you... freaks me right out heh.

I guess I can talk about the sniper gunplay next since it's the main part of the game heh... well? It's handled quite nicely and the x-ray mode is improved over the second game in the series... but it's odd, sometimes the bullet cam gets confused and flies at full speed instead of slowing down or fails to recognize a double kill (can happen if enemies are too close together) but the rest of it works great. The controls are just about perfect... I say just about as I wish it had a button to toggle what shoulder you're looking over. it's annoying when trying to come around some corners if you're not hugging said corner to try and force the camera to pan shoulders...

The campaign is actually quite the nice length as it took me 16.2 hours to beat so I feel it's actually a really nice length to it. The environments are varied and they don't feel the same which is nice since of course the gameplay options are a bit limited.. snipe, run away and return and snipe seems to work the best. It does feel like a bit of a gameplay flaw that enemies can't figure out where you are if you quickly run away and return to the same spot while they're in caution mode (yellow compass warning)... because if I ran away and came back in real life? They'd still figure out I'm in the same spot kind-of thing.

Which leads me into AI... they're decent in this game but they give up WAYYY too easily. I mean... I just sniped two of your comrades! They're dead near you!!! What do you mean you're already returning to normal patrol? Aren't you worried that you're probably next? Hahaha.... So sometimes when I feel like a challenge? I'd place anti-personel mines at the bottom of stairs or ladders leading to me and set up... and then they never charge me. Instead they just keep tossing grenades at me... so that sucked. I'd recommend to other players doing the singleplayer to just set up traps in front and below where you want to snipe in positions you figure where the enemies will try and toss grenades from. I've also had AI run off bridges to their deaths and also run into fire from a left over explosion and get themselves killed haha... so yeah, AI isn't the best in this game and if I did a future playthrough I'd definitely do the hardest difficulty.

So? 16.2 hours for the singleplayer campaign and I got it on a weekend sale. I'd definitely recommend it on those sales for the singleplayer. Tbh I don't really see myself doing multiplayer as I'm not the best at sniping haha so I'll keep my multiplayer gameplay to the likes of World of Tanks. So? If you enjoy

reviewText:
Sniper Elite 3 (SE3) takes place in Northern Africa, which is a theatre often neglected in WWII games. Usually games focus on the European Theatre (western and/or eastern fronts) and slightly less often, the Pacific Theatre. That's a nice change and presents a locale that hasn't been overused.

Something I also like about North Africa is that despite it being mostly a rocky desert, there is still plenty of environmental plant life to make the scenary appear not quite as depressing. I remember in Sniper Elite v2 (SEv2) thinking that the constant use of broken and blasted buildings became quite tiring, despite it being accurate for the location.

SE3 brings in slight RPG aspects, in that your equipment has various stats. The rifles in particular are interesting because you can greatly modify them using parts you find as you play. That said, many of the better" rifles and pistols are only available in DLC packages
date: but it's entirely possible to play through the whole game and do exceptionally well without ever spending a dime on any DLC.\n\nThe overall game mechanics are similar to SEv2. On easier difficutly levels you don't have to account for gravity (bullet drop) or wind
recommended: and pressing the focus button (the default is "E") enhances your zoom and slows down time. You have a limited amount of focus and if you expend it before firing
hoursPlayed: you'll zoom out and time will resume as normal. Fortunately
voteText: focus replenishes by itself.\n\nHead shots are preferable to body shots
helpfulPercent: although I've managed to kill enemies after hitting them in the leg. You can perforate major blood vessels and organs (seen through an x-ray view when hitting the enemy)
votesHelpful: which the game acknowledges
votesTotal: but I don't know if that really makes a difference as far as killing them goes. I believe the game really just takes into account general location damage
votesFunny: so a high velocity shot to the abdomen might result in a kill
commentsCount: regardless of it tearing apart the intestines or kidneys.\n\nRemaining undetected is a major part of SE3. You can do this by using your sidearm (assuming you've taken either the Welrod or the HDM
column16: both of which have suppressors attached to them)
column17: stabbing an unsuspecting enemy in the back
column18: or using noise to hide your sniper shots. Noise cover can range from artillery fire to PA announcements to sabotaging a generator.\n\nAlthough you have a secondary weapon (which can be anything from a Thompson submachine gun to a Panzerschrek
column19: which is essentially a rocket launcher)
column20: using it will undoubtedly cause a ton of noise
column21: thereby attracting scores of enemy soldiers who will overwhelm you on anything except the lowest difficultly level. Even then
column22: it's still fairly easy to die
column23: so it's best to avoid that scenario entirely if at all possible.\n\nUnlike SEv2
column24: enemies DO NOT suddenly pop up out of nowhere. Reinforcements can be called in (usually through scripted events)
column25: but you won't have to deal with inching forward after clearing an area only to come upon a soldier who materialized out of thin air.\n\nThe campaign takes place over eight long missions. In contrast to SEv2
column26: which relied entirely on checkpoints
column27: SE3 allows you to save whenever and wherever you wish using manual saves and quicksaves. Some players might find this "cheap" or refer to it as "save scumming
column28:
but to me it's simply a matter of convenience, which lets me play for as long or as little as I choose.

Multiplayer takes the form of PvP and PvE Co-op. In PvP multiplayer, you play on a team and fight other players, whereas in PvE Co-op, its you and your teammate against the AI.

In co-op, you have three choices:
1. Play through the entire campaign in co-op mode.
2. Play specific downloaded missions.
3. Play unique asymetric assignments, where one player has a sniper rifle and a pistol, and the other player has a pistol, secondary weapon (such as an MP-40), and binoculars.

A shooting range has also been added as an extra single player mode, which lets you practice with all the weapons, including explosives.

No matter how good SE3 is, there are some problems.

When playing co-op, the campaign missions only use temporary checkpoint saves (as opposed to the save anywhere" method in single player)
column29: which can make for some exceptionally long game times. These checkpoints only last for the duration of the session
column31: you'll have to start over the beginning of the mission.\n\nThis has been a problem for my wife and me
column33: we don't always feel like spending four hours or so on one mission. It would be nice if the game at least saved the progress of the mission on the host's machine and allowed the players to continue where they left off.\n\nThe asymetric missions almost always include a "horde mode" component
column34: where you have to defend against waves upon waves of enemies. In a game like SE3
column35: where stealth and not being noticed is generally considered important
column36: this seems very out-of-place and if you're not ready for it
column37: quite jarring as well.\n\nSomething else that's of general annoyance is the way a weapon's stats are presented. Using a combination of white
column39: and red bars to denote standard
column41: and reduced stats (when comparing other weapons to your currently armed weapon)
column42: understanding the bars can be unclear
column43: at least at first. I would've preferred numbers instead of nondescript bars
column44: but it's not a big deal overall.\n\nIn the end
column45: would I recommend Sniper Elite 3? Absolutely. If you're the least bit interested in playing a sniper and World War II

reviewText:
Do not buy this buggy pile of ♥♥♥♥.

THREE TIMES the game has bugged out in different ways on Mission 4 that make sit impossible to continue the game. Ladders stop working, game loads you into death or loads you into a cutscene and your spotted and you have to restart from the beginning and you have lost over an hour..... for the second time in a row.

Don't even get me started on the terrible optimization if you are running a Nividea card. Rebellion is working with AMD so they don't do ♥♥♥♥ for other cards. Game ran my 780ti at 85 degrees on ultra when I can run ANYTHING else around 50. I really wish I would have purchased this on Steam to get my money back instead of doing it over at Humble.

I loved SE2, 3 has done nothing but infuriate me with how terrible it is and I will not purchase anything from Rebellion in the future.

reviewText:
This review is ENTIRELY based on CO-op play only!

The game is Good
- You cannot play it like an action game, take it slow and easy
- The game is edged towards sniper shooting therefore, only the sniper gets all the love for customizations
- Don't look for realism, it's not meant to be so
- Only 8 Missions = Almost 3 hrs or so per mission, DLC's add more
- Play co-op, a lot more fun.

What's not to like:-
- The game is not really well designed for Co-op, if one player dies, the game will start from Last check point, there is no drop in and drop off in the game, also if by chance anyone disconnects, you cannot save the game, but WILL have to play ALL the way from the START. This SUX when you've finished everything but the last objective after a 3 hr mission level.
- It is not Assassin's creed, it is not a close quarters stealth game BUT appears to be. The game actually deviates from previous Sniper Elite games in this regard as more often than not, you'll actually be taking enemies down with your silenced pistol close up.
- Close quarters is clunky, use silenced pistol instead as NOT ALL situations lend to taking silent take-downs, this is by design and incredibly silly as it's not intuitive.
- One shot from the sniper gun and the ENTIRE base is almost on you.
- Far too much emphasis on Sniper gun only, everything and the kitchen sink is thrown into it, other guns' accuracy and damage is purposely kept lower.
- Far too much emphasis on Headshots to take down, seriously! Come on. Give extra XP for it, Don't make a player shoot twice just cause he hit at the torso.
- Every mission becomes tediously long of about 3 hrs if you play it slow and hidden in the game.

reviewText: A unique gamming experience for the WW2 buffs among us.  Sniper Elite 3 has improved upon the previous games in terms of visuals and gameplay.  The ability to shoot without sound cover and rellocate has fundamentally enhanced the game.  At times the visuals can be very cinematic.  As with every game, this one is not without its faults.  Gameplay can become alittle mechanical in feel (shoot, relocate, shoot, relocate) as well as the repetitive kill cam which is intriquing  at first but became overplayed.  If I could change one thing about this game it would be the addition of more story. Missions are not very plot driven.  It feels less like a WW2 sniper adventure and more like being dropped into a map with a checklist.  All defaults aside this is still a great game worthy of a playthrough.  The Afrika Korp backdrop is well executed.  I feel that Sniper Elite 3 is a fair improvement from its predecessors and a great foundation to continue to expand the genre.

reviewText:
I bought this as i love playing the role of the lone sniper, something i did successfully with Wolfenstein.
What this game offers is a dedicated role as a sniper with varying degrees of realism with fantastic levels interesting missions and a good storyline
If you are into games where you have to think and setup your attacks and want an immersive and very challenging experience then i would recommend SE3
The game play is very rewarding and it has to be said downright frustrating at times depending on the level of realism you have selected the loadout (weapon selection & customisation) takes some setting up but once you have sorted that you can settle down and enjoy ! the setting up of a shot is very rewarding indeed waiting for the target then achieving the mission is all the stuff of latent schoolboy fantasies i thouroughly enjoyed this game im now gonna do SE V2 as i just love the whole silent killer very rewarding (years of playing Thief haha) . . . for a greater challenge there is the multiplayer which is again equal in its rewards and frustrations !!

voteText: focusing in on distant points as closer things become blurry because your eyes aren't focusing on it. Everything seems clear

reviewText:
Sniper Elite 3 (SE3) takes place in Northern Africa, which is a theatre often neglected in WWII games. Usually games focus on the European Theatre (western and/or eastern fronts) and slightly less often, the Pacific Theatre. That's a nice change and presents a locale that hasn't been overused.

Something I also like about North Africa is that despite it being mostly a rocky desert, there is still plenty of environmental plant life to make the scenary appear not quite as depressing. I remember in Sniper Elite v2 (SEv2) thinking that the constant use of broken and blasted buildings became quite tiring, despite it being accurate for the location.

SE3 brings in slight RPG aspects, in that your equipment has various stats. The rifles in particular are interesting because you can greatly modify them using parts you find as you play. That said, many of the better" rifles and pistols are only available in DLC packages
date: but it's entirely possible to play through the whole game and do exceptionally well without ever spending a dime on any DLC.\n\nThe overall game mechanics are similar to SEv2. On easier difficutly levels you don't have to account for gravity (bullet drop) or wind
recommended: and pressing the focus button (the default is "E") enhances your zoom and slows down time. You have a limited amount of focus and if you expend it before firing
hoursPlayed: you'll zoom out and time will resume as normal. Fortunately
voteText: focus replenishes by itself.\n\nHead shots are preferable to body shots
helpfulPercent: although I've managed to kill enemies after hitting them in the leg. You can perforate major blood vessels and organs (seen through an x-ray view when hitting the enemy)
votesHelpful: which the game acknowledges
votesTotal: but I don't know if that really makes a difference as far as killing them goes. I believe the game really just takes into account general location damage
votesFunny: so a high velocity shot to the abdomen might result in a kill
commentsCount: regardless of it tearing apart the intestines or kidneys.\n\nRemaining undetected is a major part of SE3. You can do this by using your sidearm (assuming you've taken either the Welrod or the HDM
column16: both of which have suppressors attached to them)
column17: stabbing an unsuspecting enemy in the back
column18: or using noise to hide your sniper shots. Noise cover can range from artillery fire to PA announcements to sabotaging a generator.\n\nAlthough you have a secondary weapon (which can be anything from a Thompson submachine gun to a Panzerschrek
column19: which is essentially a rocket launcher)
column20: using it will undoubtedly cause a ton of noise
column21: thereby attracting scores of enemy soldiers who will overwhelm you on anything except the lowest difficultly level. Even then
column22: it's still fairly easy to die
column23: so it's best to avoid that scenario entirely if at all possible.\n\nUnlike SEv2
column24: enemies DO NOT suddenly pop up out of nowhere. Reinforcements can be called in (usually through scripted events)
column25: but you won't have to deal with inching forward after clearing an area only to come upon a soldier who materialized out of thin air.\n\nThe campaign takes place over eight long missions. In contrast to SEv2
column26: which relied entirely on checkpoints
column27: SE3 allows you to save whenever and wherever you wish using manual saves and quicksaves. Some players might find this "cheap" or refer to it as "save scumming
column28:
but to me it's simply a matter of convenience, which lets me play for as long or as little as I choose.

Multiplayer takes the form of PvP and PvE Co-op. In PvP multiplayer, you play on a team and fight other players, whereas in PvE Co-op, its you and your teammate against the AI.

In co-op, you have three choices:
1. Play through the entire campaign in co-op mode.
2. Play specific downloaded missions.
3. Play unique asymetric assignments, where one player has a sniper rifle and a pistol, and the other player has a pistol, secondary weapon (such as an MP-40), and binoculars.

A shooting range has also been added as an extra single player mode, which lets you practice with all the weapons, including explosives.

No matter how good SE3 is, there are some problems.

When playing co-op, the campaign missions only use temporary checkpoint saves (as opposed to the save anywhere" method in single player)
column29: which can make for some exceptionally long game times. These checkpoints only last for the duration of the session
column31: you'll have to start over the beginning of the mission.\n\nThis has been a problem for my wife and me
column33: we don't always feel like spending four hours or so on one mission. It would be nice if the game at least saved the progress of the mission on the host's machine and allowed the players to continue where they left off.\n\nThe asymetric missions almost always include a "horde mode" component
column34: where you have to defend against waves upon waves of enemies. In a game like SE3
column35: where stealth and not being noticed is generally considered important
column36: this seems very out-of-place and if you're not ready for it
column37: quite jarring as well.\n\nSomething else that's of general annoyance is the way a weapon's stats are presented. Using a combination of white
column39: and red bars to denote standard
column41: and reduced stats (when comparing other weapons to your currently armed weapon)
column42: understanding the bars can be unclear
column43: at least at first. I would've preferred numbers instead of nondescript bars
column44: but it's not a big deal overall.\n\nIn the end
column45: would I recommend Sniper Elite 3? Absolutely. If you're the least bit interested in playing a sniper and World War II
column46: there's no reason for me to not recommend this game."

reviewText:
This is without doubt the worst game i have ever played in my life.

The name is misleading for starters. First word, sniper, is very incorrect as you constantly get penalised for using the sniper rifles. Most levels only have two or three areas where noise covers the rifles sound (some levels only have one though, like the kill hitler mission) an these locations are only good for one of two kills before you have to move on. Also to me sniper kind of implies long range kills, like shooting someone several hundred meters away. However my longest kill is around 200 meters which isnt really very far at all. Second word, elite, once again suggests that were in control of a highly skilled soldier. However i seemed to have to play as a soldier who cant run for more than a few meters, seems to have some illness that makes his arms shake/body twitch, and has difficulty shooting a hostile soldier at 10m. How this guy got sniper training is beond me, I guess he found a sniper rifle early in the war and no-one thought to question him having it. The mass inaccuracy of the sidearms is just mind boggling, and i cant believe anyone would be that inept at shooting, military or not.

Gameplay wise the game plays like a crap version of metal gear solid. You sneak around a few african locations shooting people at close range with the silenced pistol, the only gun thats sort of usable for the most part of the game. The hostiles dont seem that bothered about you being there and dont seem that bothered about catching you. I dont speak german but im guessing most the germans go 'Oh look, that british sniper shot hans, but i cant see any snipers so i guess things are fine and we should go back to standing around.' The game doesnt even replace fallen guards or raise the alarm on discovery so hiding the bodes is a complete waste of time. When the german soldiers do actually find you, maybe you used your sniper rilfe, bad player your sniper rifle is just too look at, they either telepathically tell everyone where you are leading to the whole base looking for you for a few minutes before deciding you've probably gone home and go back to slacking off. Or they just stare at you for several seconds before raising the alarm, which brings a few soldiers over to have a quick look for you.

Theres a few other things that really bring this game down and the bullet balistics and the kill cam mechanic doesnt really salvage this game. After the first level the game is basically sneak here, then sneak there, then sneak away. With really boring (assassinate the guy in a truck which can basically only be done with mines) or pointless side objectives (disable the spotlights, that you can only disable after sneaking past them) was the final nail in the coffin for me for me.

Game has so many good ideas, but they're just awfully done.
